description:
Quite a fancy place. The food had the greatest texture and flavors. I would say my favorites were the drinks by far and the dessert really blew me away. 

The cocktails are really made to perfection. They are a bit pricey, but definitely worth it to try. My beef was so perfectly cooked and seasoned. The waiter poured the sauce over the meat and veggies as it was set down in front of me. Nice touch. 

The dessert sounded pleasant from the description, but when we actually tried it the flavors were insane. The texture of the cookie/cracker part really went well with the pudding/sauce part and the ice cream. This isn't a great description of what we had, but WOW it's hard to explain. I've never had anything like it and I definitely want to come back again to try out more of the menu. I just probably want to wait for a special event cuz $$$. 

Ambiance: 5/5
Food and drink: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Overall Experience: 5/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
We went for my wife's birthday dinner. Our hope was that given this is a upscale place, the service and food would be amazing; we could not have been more wrong!

I booked a table and mentioned that we are coming to celebrate a birthday. At the restaurant, no one wished my wife and no treats on birthdays. It looked like the front person was very busy and did not read on her computer screen that we are here for a birthday.

We were seated on a very small table in a sad corner. Drinks and food order was taken, food came but drinks came at least after 30 minutes. A restaurant like this should be providing very good service.

The food was bad--they took some classic Indian dishes and made a mess out of them. Everything was extra buttery, their nan-bread were like grocery store nans, and the rotis were cold. 

Overall, for the money and time we spent on this place, we could have eaten a much better meal at any of the normal Indian restaurants in Bay Area.
author: Akshay S.

description:
The moment I walked into Rooh, I immediately fell in love with their interior design! Definitely had a more upscale Indian cuisine vibe than I expected. 

For food, I had the chicken koliwada, the chutney sampler, masala chai tea, butter chicken, and the tandoori malai mushroom. My favorites were the koliwada, the chutney sampler, and the mushrooms. 
The chicken koliwada was slightly crunchy on the outside, and so soft and moist on the inside. I especially loved the Kulcha in the chutney sampler, as it was filled with this delicious mixture of green peas & goat cheese. And the mushrooms, wow. My love for mushrooms has never been so well-suited for a dish until now. There were so many types of juicy mushrooms, and the garlicky saltiness of them went so well with the polenta upma. 

Deeeelicious! Definitely coming back again to try out other dishes.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
I liked the classy ambience, excellent for a night out with a date, intimate but not pretentious. Came here just for appetizers so we had an order of dahi puri and an order of assorted pappads and crisps. I appreciated the contrasting textures of the thin crispy dahi puri shells and the creamy yogurty and flavorful filling. Definitely a delectable treat and would get again. The pappads were good for a try, but did not stand out enough for me to try again. We ran out of the crisps before we ran out of the chutney. Asking for more crisps is another 5 dollars. 

All in all, I think the flavors for the two dishes I had can be had at many lower end Indian restaurants and as such may not justify the high end price. You are likely paying more for the precisely engineered texture combination of the dahi puris and, of course, the location/ambience. Would consider returning to try other dishes if I am feeling like a diva.
author: Kent L.

description:
I had my first contemporary/progressive Indian experience at ROOH and it was pretty eye opening. 

My Indian food experience spans from $8.99 lunch buffets to this one hole in the wall (and very, very questionable) joint that everyone goes to in my hometown with $5.99 masala. Seeing Indian food being elevated to this level was definitely quite an experience for me!

Sarah K. and I ordered multiple things to share:
+ chutney sampler w garlic naan - loved the variety of all the chutneys
+ potato doughnut tikki spinach pakoda
+ burrata tandoori squash
+ tandoori monk fish - this was my favorite dish of the night 
+ cashew cake - this was great as well

Overall, everything was really flavorful, perhaps too flavorful? Each bite was an explosion of flavor, multiply that by the variety of dishes and there's five different flavor bombs going off in your mouth. There were definitely times I needed some naan or rice to wipe my taste buds of everything that's going on. 

ROOH's great for those who want to experience a modern take on Indian food in a contemporary setting. Just be prepared for your tastebuds to be excited, confused, intrigued, surprised, overwhelmed, enlightened, etc. all at the same time!
author: Laverne N.

description:
Really wonderful place in soma. The ambience is plush and fancy - the food is the right mix of authentic and fusion. Such a delight to eat here. We tried most of their veggie dishes - jackfruit tacos, paneer chili roll, dahi Puri, pani Puri, aloo tikki were all amazing. Kadai paneer and paneer kulcha are pretty good too. 

Good service and great location -  highly recommend this indian fusion restaurant in the city.
author: Eshita S.

description:
If you've ever eaten with me then you know that I'm a meal sharer, meaning I want to order lots of different dishes and have everyone share them together. So, when I find myself at dinner in a larger group I get excited thinking about how many different dishes we can order. And that is what happened to me at ROOH, where I ate dinner in a group of 8. It's possible that we order too many dishes, but hey, sometimes the food is so good it's hard to say no. Honestly we did order a lot, so much that listing it all out *might* make be a little embarrassed, but I will say that not one dish disappointed and I would be happy to order and eat any of them again. Although I'm also inclined to try some things on the menu we didn't get to.

Beyond the food, the cocktails were on point, and the ordering of them is this interesting wheel of spirits and mixtures. Plus the beer and wine list was definitely decent. Our service was top notch and the atmosphere  was really lovely - it was warm and welcoming for a group while also being cozy enough for a date if you were looking for that vibe. I highly recommend ROOH for dates, friends, or groups and I'll be happy to return here on another trip to SF!
author: Tiffany N.

description:
I've been to Rooh twice and had slightly different experiences.

The first time was for brunch with a large group. We ordered mostly vegetarian dishes and the food was fantastic! IMHO it's really hard to get fancy with Indian food and make it taste good, because Indian spices have such strong flavors, but the chef at Rooh did such an excellent job. Classic dishes were modified to make it experimental without compromising on the taste (if anything it tasted better).

The second time was for a birthday dinner. This time we got more traditional dishes like butter chicken and a chickpea curry and were a little let down. It's not like the food tasted bad, but it was definitely not memorable. The service was excellent and they gave us celebratory dessert on the house (the chocolate cake; which tasted okay) , but after my first experience, I expected the food to taste much better.

I guess it depends on what you order, but if you get it right, it's a great experience. I would definitely go back here again for a celebration and hope to get my mind blown :)
author: Divya S.

description:
3.5 stars

Interior that matches its modern take on Indian cuisine. The food on the other hand, failed to impress.

We started with the tuna bhel and duck shikampuri, both were solid starts to the meal. For the tuna dish, imagine poke, but mixed with melon, crunchy rice bits, and some spice. The shikampuri packed an even stronger hit of spice while tasty, unfortunately overpowered any duck flavor.

For our large plate we ordered the tandoori monkfish which can only be summed up as underwhelming. With strong flavors coming from our small plates, I expected the monkfish to deliver on what Indian dishes usually accomplish quite easily - depth in flavor. The fish was a bit tough and over cooked, and the sad "curry" that it was sitting in was anything but that; I would instead liken it to lentils in a bland sauce. 

Fortunately for us we decided to order the milk cake for dessert which was perhaps the best dish of the night. It wasn't too sweet despite having a rich caramel sauce. I only wish that they included more than a tiny sliver per serving!
author: Linda M.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while and finally got the chance this past Saturday night! We made the reservation pretty last minute, but we were able to get a table at 8:30 and were seated almost immediately upon arrival. Make sure you check it you're reservation is for high seating or a normal table if you have a preference!

For the food, we order the cauliflower koliwada, fresh oysters, paneer pinwheel and garlic naan. The cauliflower koliwada was by far my favorite- it wasn't greasy at all and the flavors all melded really well; I could have eaten a whole second plate on my own. 

The oysters were also good, but there seemed to be a little ice in them, which was kind of off-putting. The paneer pinwheel was also good, but would maybe have wanted more paneer instead of just the two pieces we were given! The garlic naan was standard, nothing outstanding of the ordinary; it probably could have been a little fluffier for me, but that's a preference thing.
author: Sonia S.

description:
We came here a little while back to celebrate a birthday. It was a quick walk from everyone's offices and we were able to secure a great reservation time.

From the moment we were seated - our waitress was fantastic. She was exceptional at listening to our menu questions and she was pro-active at checking in with the kitchen to ensure that our table's dietary preferences/needs were addressed. 

Rooh's creative drink menu was a fun way to start the meal and  each drink we ordered was dynamic and fresh. 

I ordered the Beef Short Ribs Curry and replaced the garlic mash with extra veggies. The ribs were phenomenal. Though a little fatty, they were so tender and bursting with pronounced flavor. I thoroughly enjoyed the asparagus that accompanied my dish.

Our table also ordered the Paneer Pinwheel and the Butter Chicken. Both dishes were served in a similar rich creamy sauce and were devoured with huge satisfied smiles. Rooh's Garlic Naan was ideal for sopping up the dreamy extra sauce.

For elevated seasonal Indian Food with well-thought-out cocktails - Rooh is your spot. We adored our whole meal and we were particularly excited that we were able to catch up in a quiet dining area - with attentive service.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I had this bookmarked for a while and expected the food to be good but it was even better than I had ever imagined.  Every bite was perfection, a symphony of just balance flavors.  Honestly anything you order off the menu will probably be divine.

You can tell they put a lot of thought process into every dish.  Definitely order a kulcha to start with.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I am all about the bourgie dining! Trust me, my friends will tell you stories for months! This place... not even close to a "old money elegant place to eat." 
This place smells of a want to be upscale restaurant with nothing upscale about it. 
Their menu is a joke. They turned some of the classic meals into pretentious dishes. What most people, Indian and non Indians alike know as tikka masala, they turned into "...pinwheel...blah blah blah." 

A dinner for two cost $86.00, and neither one of the two were happy with the food. 

There are some things that are meant to be left in their natural state...Indian food is one of those things. It's already classy and elegant in its authentic self...there is no need to mess with it.

The chefs here made the novice mistake of taking a cuisine that's already perfect and tried to make it something that it's not... "non-Indian." 

For anyone looking for the authentic Indian food experience, I highly recommend you DO NOT go to this place.

It's a waste of money and a downright disappointment in terms of the food.
author: Snneha N.

description:
Bought a brunch voucher for this on Gilt City. So much food with two small plates and two entrees. We had the lamb curry, chicken biryani, tofu and goat cheese kebab, and tuna. Amazing. The tuna had great chunks of vegetables and was perfectly spiced. The kebab had a great texture and was served with roasted beets. 

The fermented turmeric sorbet was a perfect end to the meal. 

Everything was beautifully presented and well prepared. 

I had a lot of trouble calling the restaurant to make a reservation. They don't seem to answer the phone. So book through their website or use OpenTable like I did. 

Service was well-informed, professional and very friendly. 

Beautiful Space. 

Moulton Brown lotion in washrooms.
author: Tim P.

description:
Celebrated my mom's birthday here a few months ago. We tend to go to fancy places on special occasions, usually a steakhouse or French restaurant. I never crave Indian food, but my dad recommended ROOH. ROOH ticks off the "fancy" mark in that it is elegant inside. I especially love the bold colors of the furniture and decor. Service was also spot on. As for food, the dishes are definitely more refined, and with that expect pricier than normal.

My family of 5 shared...
- Chicken 65: Complementary! Such a nice surprise.
- Chutney Sampler: Naan with 3 different types of dipping chutneys. My favorite was the avocado/yogurt, but they also have chili/peanut and tomatillo/green mango.
- Fresh Oyster: Baked, not raw. Came with 5, so that worked out.
- Duck Shikampuri: This was my least favorite dish. Only came with 3 small disks and did not taste like duck at all.
- Tandoori Mushroom: I liked this, but the parmesan mousse was a tad too overpowering for my parents.
- Chilean Sea Bass: Served with mashed potatoes. Delicious, wished the portion was bigger.
- Lamb Chop: Not really chops since the meat was cut off the bone into 3 little cubes. Somewhat a disappointment.

We also got some cocktails from the cocktail wheel menu, as well as ordered more sides of naan and saffron rice. For dessert, we ordered 2 dishes (forgot what they were called). One was a chocolate cake and one was a coconut rose tart. They were both really good, except they only gave us half a tart... I know it's artistic, but did they really need to skimp on that too?
author: Jessica C.

description: Amazing creative and delicious food!  Very beautiful place and the service was excellent.  Of course the prices of the dishes reflect this, but this takes Indian food to a new level. There were plenty of choices for a vegetarian like me and I left stuffed.  I would definitely recommend this place for a date or special occasion.
author: Megan M.

description:
Came here for lunch and was so disappointed. Thought it was funny that the host asked if we had reservations when the restaurant only had 4 tables full. We ordered the butter chicken spicy, lamb curry spicy, some lentils and chickpeas. The butter chicken was not spicy and only had 5 pieces, lamb curry was ok, lentils were pretty good, but the worst was the chickpeas which was overly salty.

TL:DR - pros: fast, clean, Nan was so good; cons: over priced (our meal was close to $100 and this was lunch!), Food under seasoned or over seasoned, food came out lukewarm
author: Lo L.

description:
Came for lunch with the coworkers. 5 stars for service and food!!

I had accidentally made the reso for the following week and they were so nice to make room for a table.

We all ordered the curry of the day with chicken and garlic naan. YUM O! It had a little kick, wish it was amped up a bit. The garlic naan was still soft and didn't have any burnt parts (I hate that). It also had the perfect amount of garlic!

Will be coming back to try the buttered chicken!
author: Jerrica N.

description:
The Chakra drink menu as I like to call it is a great thought. Kudos to whoever thought of that for laying out the difference of the tastes of the drinks from sweet, sour, etc. The way the drinks are served is amazing. An old fashioned it actually served in an old fashioned style Indian alcohol bottle with an engraved piece of ice in a glass on the side.
Awe inspiring and mouthwatering starters selection which lives up to the description. The service is great. The food is awesome. I would highly recommend getting the Hyderabad Keema which is served with a potato moose on top. The butter chicken is similar to what you would get somewhere in Delhi. The naan is top rated!!! The chicken malai kabab is a must have as well. Vegetarians please don't feel disheartened, the dahi puri and every selection of vegetarian option on the menu is worth trying.
Yes the place is expensive but this place defines what progressive Indian actually means.
Good way to represent progressive India. Big ups!
Will be back for sure and will recommend this place to as manny people as possible.
author: Akshay B.

description:
This place was really a great find when i visiting the Bay Area! When I walked in, it had a dark and classy ambience to the restaurant. I had to catch a flight within the next hour and our server made sure to bring everything out within a 30-40 minute span! 

My family and I ordered the duck seekh kabob, cheesy malai kufta, tuna chaat, chickpeas Kadai, butter chicken, and vegetable pillai. 

My items were the duck seekh kabob (so soft and tender) as well as the malai kufta. It comes in a steaming hot plate where cheese and spices are oozing out! So delicious!!! I would not order the butter chicken though (could be cooked a lot better). 

I really enjoyed that we did not just have one server but multiple bringing out various small plates. Overall, I like the concept of tapas plates at an Indian restaurant and would come visit again.
author: Safia K.

description:
4.5 stars. I had a friend who interned at State Bird Provisions, so anything he had to say about food & beverage... I was all ears. Out of all the restaurants in Mission Bay, he said ROOH was one of the best. It took me a few months to visit, but Nina Y. and I finally made reservations for our weekly dinner.

This restaurant reminds me of August 1 Five. Or the other way around. Not sure which one opened first. Probably ROOH. Anyways, both have an upscale vibe, which I love. Customer service is fabulous here. Our waiter checked in with us just the right number of times and at a perfect frequency.

Nina and I ordered cocktails from the awesome "wheel" menu, which divides up the flavors of cocktails they offer. Perfect for decision-making. I went with the "Coromandel Salli" which has whiskey and mango. Right up my alley. So good, too. Would highly recommend. 

We ordered a few different dishes for dinner, including the chutney sampler, tuna bhel, gun powder scallop, and lamb chop. They were all amazing, except I thought the lamb chop was a little dry, and the accompanying moussaka wasn't impressive. I love the variety of flavors in the chutney sampler, the presentation of the tuna was exquisite, and the scallop... well you can't go wrong with scallop.

Fantastic restaurant to visit whether you're in the Mission Bay neighborhood or just visiting. I definitely recommend reservations because it was quite busy when we were here. Everyone was celebrating a different occasion, whether a date, family outing, birthday, or business meeting. Perfect for all!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Excellent food, it's a expensive but it is worth the money! Great service and very good quality food. I enjoyed the chef's creativity especially with the paneer roll! 
Other dishes we tried were fried quail, chutney platter that came with an assortment of naans, malai chicken kofta, Jackfruit tacos, and phirni and chocolate pave for desserts were to die for!

It was 5 of us, we just had the appetizers and desserts or total came out to be $110. The overall experience was excellent!
author: Ritupriya P.

description:
The food is delicious. After a lot of cancelling and rebooking a table, we finally went yesterday. Yelp gives you option to do a reservation before hand and it's pretty good. We tried the chutney sampler with the breads, yogurt kebab, cauliflower dish, and pinwheel paneer for main course. Everything was super tasty but the garlic naan was decent and same was the kulcha. The pinwheel paneer was very much like the Punjabi shahi paneer just that paneer was rolled up. We also tried the pink city martini and it was nice.

The service was great and overall experience was fantastic, although the restaurant is a little expensive for the kind of food they serve, it was not very exceptional. I sort of expected a little more from them.
author: Bhawna J.

description:
This was my third time at Rooh, except this time I went with a vegetarian friend and did not order any meat dishes. I was a bit worried but Rooh did not disappoint me. 

We got the cauliflower 65 and the potato tikki for small plates. Note: the cauliflower 65 is definitely bigger than a small plate (it's enough to be the only shared appetizer for two). Highly recommend getting the cauliflower- well flavored, not too spicy, and the sour cream + peanut chutney compliment the tangy flavor really well. 

Potato tikki was my least favorite dish here (although it was still okay). I usually love potato tikkis but it was 70% kale+spinach. 

The paneer pinwheel is probably the best take on paneer makhani I have had in San Francisco. It's hard for me to describe what a good garlic naan is until I taste it. The naan here was amazing. 

Dal Makhani is also pretty great (although you can find even better dal makhani in South Bay at a few places). 

Overall, Rooh continues to be my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco. Will not hesitate to come here for a fourth time.
author: Karanveer M.

description:
4 stars is a bit generous given the challenges with service (starters nearly done before drinks arrived, a mix up with entrees, bread finally coming out as entrees were nearly finished), but our server was gracious and helpful and each course met my high expectations. 

The drink menu presentation is fun with unexpected flavors. I decided to be a bit adventurous and try the Patna Fizz, which listed mushroom as an ingredient. Our server assured me it wasn't mushroom-forward, but infused in the syrup making to balance the sweetness. He was right - the flavor only appeared as a light note at the end and was a bit odd, but I'm still happy I tried it. 

The dishes (Potato Tikki, Paneer Pinwheels, and Coconut Bread Pudding) were are wonderfully flavorful, beautiful, elevated interpretations of ones you may be familiar with, and delicate. My only challenge is I have to be in the right mood for delicate, and that's not often. The Potato Tikki consisted of a traditional potato patty topped with kale chips, a delightful mousse, and individual raspberry cells (must be so painstaking). I hadn't before seen Paneer in any form but cubes; the pinwheels were good but the dish was mostly the surrounding curry, which was the star. Finally, the bread pudding was more like French toast than bread pudding, but didn't stop me from going at it. 

The ambiance of the place is a bit disjointed - they're clearly going for upscale and sleek but the diners are mostly quite casual even at 7pm on a Saturday (T-shirts, hoodies, sneakers, young kids climbing around). I know it's SF - and SOMA at that - but for such a nice (aka expensive) meal, the experience should match. Casual and inviting is great; the just-rolled-off-the-couch look is not. If they can solve this split personality, it could be a place I'd be excited to take others I want to impress.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Lovely upscale Indian in SOMA, perfect for business lunches. The space is gorgeous and luxe, with plush velvet booths, curtained off nooks, and colorful tiles. The food is expertly done, exploding with flavor... I had some of the best salmon ever here. The dishes are true works of art, and service is polished and unintrusive.

Definitely feels like a show-offy business meeting kind of spot, but could also be really swanky for date night. The decor alone is photo-worthy, along with the food.
author: Nique F.

description:
Food fell a bit short of my expectations. Made reservations for a Friday evening (very easy to make) and had no problems there. The inside of the restaurant is gorgeous and it was such a huge space. 

My friend wasn't able to drink alcohol at the time, and the restaurant was unable to cater to her needs by making any of the alcoholic cocktails virgin for her. This was a bit unfortunate as the non alcoholic options were limited. All of the food was mediocre, but I was most disappointed by the chicken dish. The chicken was so dry, even when doused in sauce and we didn't even have the will to finish it. As much as I wanted to love this place, unfortunately this dish ruined my entire experience here.
author: Megan K.

description:
Pujan, Sujan and Team ROOH is absolutely fantastic. My favorite Indian fancy place in the Bay Area. Rooh definitely elevates desi khana with a twist to absolute fine dining experience. We walked into a classy place, hoping the food is good. It was FANTASTIC! The service was great, the people friendly. And the real star- food!

I have been a fan of theirs since Olive Bar days in Mumbai and must say, Rooh did not disappoint. The Rooh team is honest and passionate about their food. We know this because we wanted to take something to-go and the chef, in his really cool manner told us, although good for business, I would rather you have it here. It shows he is so passionate about his art that he wants you to experience it right then and there, his way. 

The food is the star here- Think of every bite you take as a surprise. A very nice, pleasant, almost divine surprise with textures and taste on your tongue- aha, what beauty to look at and even more beautiful to taste.

Some of our favorites included the Dahi Puri with avocado. The dahi mousse was yum- light, airy, amazing.

We also had jackfruit curry which had semolina jaali on the top. The crunch that added to the curry was pretty good. Also, the jackfruit balls were perfect crisp!

Lastly, our favorite was saffron tart- again, fantastic light and airy mousse and perfect sweet with a crisp tart and gold leaves on top. 

Even the petit fours were a surprise- one looked like a regular chocolate bar, but a bite into it and you would taste the gulkand! and other was aam papad (mango flavored) toffee which would melt in your mouth.

We LOVED Rooh and we will be back! If in the area, definitely go there!
author: Megha U.

description:
If you are indian chat lover + love to experience fine dine. Go for it.
Top 100 listed restaurant gives you enrich taste, service. I like the their way of giving short description of the food. 
Good ambiance. Price at bit higher side.
Two people $40-50 includes 3-4 different dishes.
Do make reservations to avoid wait to get table.
Suggestions:
Must try aalo tikki
author: Afreen P.

description:
everything was tasty

starter of potato tikki like a flavorful hashbrown with sourcream

also a spicy lentil kulcha - fluffy bread with nice chutney

butter chicken is tender, sauce is tomatoey, poured over their soft fresh naan. wonderful texture

nagpur naranji was ok, a little expensive for what's essentially soda water with orange juice

Out of the desserts we shared, the cashew cake was the best. Succulent cake in a delicious sauce with an almondy thandai ice cream

runner up was the milk cake - sort of a cake with milk nougat in between each layer

finally, the flavors of the strawberry rhubarb tart were not meshing together as well

arrival of food was a little slow, but service incredibly patient with our large group
author: Marshall Y.

description:
ROOH SF is probably my favorite spot for modern Indian foo. Presentation is amazing, food is delicious, ambiance is very lively, and the service is great! 

I would highly recommend ROOH for a date, anniversary, or birthday dinner! 

5 full stars
author: MrJoshyaya ..

description:
This place has really good ambience. They have online reservation option which works out well. I was keen to try out this Indian restaurant and was expecting a lot. I was limited to vegetarian options on the visit and decided to try few items that looked exciting on the menu. Some of the breads were drier and not soft (as they should be). The beets were slightly on the sour side too. The croquettes were delicious. The paneer pinwheel was good but it was nothing different from the regular paneer butter masala. The pinwheel simply meant that the paneer was rolled instead of cut cubes. So, in terms of flavor, I felt that it was a little muted to be really Indian. The taste seems to be tuned for an audience that does not like lot of spice. 
The service was good and we were looked after well. 
I gave similar comments on their feedback form and was sorry to see the staff disappointed.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place for quite some time. Gone are the days where Amber India dominated the Indian food scene and any Indian restaurant that makes SF Chronicle's "Top 100 Restaurants" List is immediately on my "To Try" List.

We decided to go with the tasting menu option in order to get a full sampling of the menu. My parents decided to get the beverage pairing option as well. I have to say that ironically, the best parts came later in the meal. Normally my experience has been that the appetizers are the stars and the main courses are a little too much.  The pani puri/dahi puri were a little underwhelming. I get the need to make it more exciting in an upscale restaurant but I feel like they could have taken a chapter out of August 1 Five's book and had different "pani's" instead of trying to have the same old pani puri. The goat cheese and pea kulcha was also very underwhelming. I wish that they had stuffed it with goat cheese rather than integrate it with the naan batter. It would have provided more flavor.

I was starting to get a little worried at this point but then when the lamb ribs, kebab, and tikki came, I began to feel a little better. They were what you would expect from an upscale Indian restaurant. The monk fish/asparagus were even better and finally the main dishes were out of this world. Everything, especially the beef, was cooked perfectly and was so tasty. Finally the dessert was amazing and finished the meal perfectly.

We got the raita, daal, saffron rice, garlic naan, and papad to accompany the meal. They were good but nothing extraordinary. The papad however, was extremely well put together; they had different kinds of papads and chutneys, all tasty, and I LOVE papad, so that means something. The wine pairings were also very well put together and I must say that I was impressed.

Overall, this restaurant did not blow me away, but I can at least see how this place has knocked Amber India off the top Indian restaurants in the Bay Area.
author: Kunal N.

description:
I LOVED IT. (plus, our waiter was super cute :P) 

First of all, make sure you order cocktails - such a scientific and well thought out menu. Drinks actually taste like indian food, sounds weird? but ohmygod, SO GOOD. 

Second of all, butter chicken was amazing, arguably the best I've had (in the states). Chicken was tender, flavorful, aromatic, and drenched in a sea of mildly spiced curry sauce. 

Third of all, presentation & tableware were all well thought out and beautiful. 

Lastly, order both the naan & roti. 

Only thing to note - portions are on the smaller side. By all means, order more dishes to try and share :)
author: Dana Z.

description:
The food was very good. I enjoyed my butter chicken very much. I also enjoyed my Pink City drink. 

The service? I expected more with how much we ended up paying. It was overwhelming and underwhelming for our party of 10. Let me explain. 

When we arrived at our table, our server offered to get us "celebratory champagne." Really? Right off the bat you want to try and sell us champagne? And then he suggested that we order 8 large plates + "at least" 8 small plates to share...and he repeated this three times because he really wanted us to do this.

We politely declined and ordered 1 large plate each, 
rice and naan to share, and 2 orders of the sample platter. This was more than enough food. The large plates alone would have been perfectly fine so I can't imagine what we would have done with the 8 additional small plates.

For a server who was pushy about the way we ordered, he and his team had a very slow response to my friend while she had an allergic reaction. They just kept staring at us waiting for a reaction instead of asking her what she needed. Fortunately we acted quick and got her out of there to get a benadryl and epipen. That situation was dramatic and difficult but your staff should have some kind of protocol. 

The up-selling to get you to buy more is a turn off. So unfortunately, even though the food was good, I don't think I'd come back.
author: Stacey D.

description:
Went here for dinner on a Thursday evening and it was quite busy. The restaurant has a nice ambiance and so would be good for a cozy dinner.

Tried the following dishes

Beetroot Murabba - A deconstructed version of a traditional Indian homemade pickle. The dish look brilliant and I feel did a great job of capturing the flavors of the actual pickle. Sweet and spicy / sour at the same time. 

Jackfruit Dumplings - A typical Indian curry dish, consisting of Jackfruit balls in a creamy sauce. I expected more out of this dish. Being the expensive restaurant that this is, it tasted like a curry dish I could have at any other Indian restaurant. The dumplings tasted more like Potato dumplings and I did not taste any Jackfruit flavor. The sauce did not have any unique flavor either.

Masala Chai Chocolate Pave - This dessert also left me wishing for more. I did not get any Masala Chai flavor out in it. 

The presentation of every dish was great, but I expected some innovative flavors or ingredients from the dishes.
author: Umang D.

description:
My girlfriend had a gift card to use up here, so we went for a double date with her sister and her partner! The gift card was something of a blessing since we could order generously without worrying too much about the price (which could have been prohibitive otherwise).

We ordered a cocktail each, three appetisers, two mains and a couple of desserts to share. The cocktails were...unusual. Generally good but certainly on the spicier side. If you don't mind your cocktails tasting more your dinner than usual, it's an experience.

While the meat dishes are usually the reason to go to places like Rooh, I really enjoyed the vegetarian dishes we ordered. In particular, the Spiced Chickpea Cake went down well across our table, as did the Grain and Vegetable Pulao (which is quinoa, not rice as you may have expected).

Dessert was one hit, one miss (or two misses if you ask my girlfriend). As other reviewers have suggested, the milk cake is worth trying. I loved the tangy, creamy flavour. Others in my group did not (which was great - I got to eat all of it). The rose & rhubarb tart, which is vegan, was really not to our taste - to be point where we unanimously agreed after a bite to send it back.

The high ceilings and a simple but classy decor made this feel like a proper "date night" spot.

Service was generally good until a large group came and sat opposite us - at which point our waiter all but disappeared. This was after we'd eaten, but made it take around 20 minutes to get our cheque. Ugh.

Indian fusion is always a bit variable, and that certainly seemed to be the case here. That said, for the most part, the dishes we ordered went down well. I'd consider returning here for a special occasion!
author: Sunil S.

description:
Where to begin: Exquisite cuisine AND excellent service all the way around from the hosts to the food runners. Our mother's bday celebration was a success from the appetizers to the desserts!

Giovanni was an attentive server and made it a point to make sure our elder grandmother was taken care of- shout out Giovanni.

Roger and Miguel behind the beautiful bar create perfected cocktails. Patna Fizz is my go-to.

Dahi Puri, chicken kofta, halibut, duck were all amazing: I have never tasted these flavors before. We did not know these flavors EXISTED! The pastry chef, Nazir, has truly outdone himself with the cashew cake and all the sorbets were to die for. 

Joey was great and made sure our table was taken care of. Johnny announced dishes the moment they hit the table with perfection and all our questions: Johnny had the answer to. Atmosphere is elegant and relaxed inside. And if you decide to eat outside with your dog, the staff will make sure your pet is taken care of with a water bowl!?

Amazing take on progressive Indian AND you can bring your furry friend? Make sure to book your reservation!
author: Krista O.

description: Good ambience, service and food. We enjoyed our dinner here. We went on a week night, the restaurant was not completely full, but had a good vibe to it. The Paneer chilli roll with the thecha was really good.
author: Shabina M.

description:
"Eek! Me thinks not" is 100% accurate... 

We went with the $70 tasting menu, and man, do I regret it! 

1. Their kale tempura over potato tikki was just okay. Unfortunately, I couldn't finish this plate because I felt like there was way too much oil over the crispy kale - I started feeling nauseous after a few bites. 
2. The asparagus pepper fry was their worst plate of the night. It was so bland and flavorless that I almost asked for salt or some sort of additional seasoning. My friend's boyfriend took one bite and couldn't even finish the rest of the dish that he asked for it to be taken away. By the way, I think that if a waiter/waitress sees that a dish has barely been touched, s/he should ask if something is wrong. Our waitress didn't even shown any concern and just asked if we were done. 
3. I'm a HUGE fan of dessert / anything sweet; however, I couldn't even finish their Masala Chai and Chocolate Pave. I must say even the brownies I buy from Safeway taste better than this. 
4. Service was extremely slow. My friend even joked, "Are they making our dessert from scratch in the back?" But what angered me the most was that after they took so long to come out with our dishes, they had the audacity to ask us to leave as soon as we paid our bill (apparently they needed our table for upcoming reservations). 

I am definitely NOT coming back here. The only thing good about this restaurant is the presentation of their food.
author: Angelina H.

description:
Visited this place for a brunch during a long weekend. The decor is nice and I love the mixture of colors and prints. Their lunch menu is pretty good, it has a good collection of individual meals which are complete on its own. I was confused between the vegetarian platter (more like an indian thali) and the cauliflower 65 (which was a combination of south indian flavors). The server suggested other than the thali the other portions are small so I got the thali.

The service was quick and nice so thats a plus. We got some drinks (the chennai colada--delicious and pink lady--good). The food was a bit too rich for my taste. It did feel like a bit main stream indian food at any other restaurant with a super rich and creamy paneer curry. I would have liked lighter accompiments but they were heavy too (dal makhni, avocado boondi raita, chole, saffron rice and naan). I would have liked some freshness like a salad, veggies or something to break the butteriness and fattiness. The naan was cooked well and was my favorite. The daal was good too. The methi malai paneer (the main element of the thali) was ok. The paneer was not the softest however I was super impressed with how smooth the curry was. The avocado raita was a nice twist. I could have done without the chole and the richness in the rice.

The chicken thali was the same with just chicken pieces instead of paneer. I did not expect a restaurant of their calibre to use the same curry for two such similar dishes.

I would visit again because the other menu items did sound interesting and they did have a good cocktail menu which I couldnt try. I would recommend getting smaller portions maybe and trying 2-3 things than getting the platter/thali. As of today, not super impressed!
author: Anuja K.

description: I was at Rooh for a work dinner.  The food was delicious, all the people visiting really enjoyed the food.  The Indian spices were definitely prevalent in most dishes and the blend of Indian and non-Indian types of food was great.  On top of that, the drink menu was fantastic.  I had the old-fashioned drink, which came with a tiny flask, and was very, very tasty.
author: Dipesh G.

description: Oh my god!!! One of the best upscale Indian restaurants in the city. The presentation and service was great. The naan was super soft. Appetizers and desserts we're creative. They could have done better on the chai though. The chai was very milky. But I am definitely going to rooh again.
author: Prerna M.

description:
I have an Indian name, so you know my review is legit. This is the best Indian place in town. Period. 

Pro tip: They have a 'black dairy dal' in the sides section of their menu, which is easy to miss. It is hands down one of the best Dal Makhni I've had in this country.
author: Alok S.

description: Best Indian I have ever had, hands down. Lovely decor, classy and attentive staff, and fabulous drinks. I will be dreaming about their homemade naan with butter chicken. Great for a group or a date. We loved all four dishes we tried!
author: Anna M.

description:
Really disappointed with the food here. Went in here with recommendations from many friends and I must say the fusion of food here doesn't taste good at all. 

I tried August one five in SF has the same concept definitely better food. 

We had couple non- alcoholic drinks and it was really bitter n didn't taste good. The presentation of food was really good but that's all it was! The food was completely off. Being an Indian, I have tried enough Indian food and fusion restaurants and this was probably on the bottom of the list.
author: Darshana S.

description:
By far my favorite Indian fusion place in the city. They take traditional Indian food to it and manage to make it better. 

The interior decor is brilliant with its use of blue as the themed color in everything. 

Special shout out to whoever came up with the idea of their drinks menu. It tells you the style of the drink (sweet, sour, packs a punch, easy on the palate etc) and that can be very helpful if you have no idea about the ingredients in the cocktail. 

10/10 will come again. 

p.s. - it's a bit on the expensive side so plan accordingly
author: Sahil B.

description:
As an Indian and a chef, I am a harsh critic of Indian food and this place stole my heart, for creativity and flavour. I was taken here for my birthday dinner by a friend and I was so glad we came here. It's chic, innovative and served modern Indian cuisine brilliantly.

The atmosphere here is trendy and chic. Clean furniture, exposed ceiling and comfortable. The cocktail list is extensive with some nice Indian fusion cocktails which were excellent and the food menu had plenty of small plates and main courses. There is also a decent sized dessert menu. 

The starters we shared of chili paneer, papadums and prawns were excellent. For main we had the lamb shank, fish and Daal. The Daal was to die for as was the fish. The lamb was cooked to perfection but lacked a bit of heat. They also gave us a couple of small courses on the house which was very nice of them :-) 

Good service and great atmosphere combined with excellent food means I will be back here again and again. A great find in town.
author: Sam S.

description:
Loved the ambience and appetizers. Dahi Puri and aloo tikki were served super quickly and finger licking good.
Main course however came after a but of wait. paneer pinwheel was an excellent concept and Rich and creamy just as we expected. 
Pindi chole were disappointing however. Nothing extraordinary. Just like we make at home. 
For tandoori roti, I was surprised to see it being so thick and under cooked from the edges. Hence one less star.
Moscow mule and chai were good. Especially lived the kettle and tea cup.
author: Neha G.

description:
We decided to try out ROOH because of the variety of dishes that they offered and it looked like it would be a really good deal to try so many dishes out. I went with a friend so we were able to try most of the dishes. The service was very attentive, maybe too much do since they were very quick to take away empty dishes, and my friend said it seemed like they were watching us to see when we were done so they could clear out the dishes. They were very good at giving us new utensils when we had a new dish and if we looked like we needed help, they were very good at coming over and seeing if we needed something. They also refilled our water quickly and we were able to get our check quickly...
Service: (5/5)
Bathroom: 
There were only two unisex bathrooms but they were clean. (5/5)

Food: (4/5)
5 course menu - $65/person

Canapes
- Pani Puri - spiced passion fruit water, avocado, tamarind
We only got one set of two pieces for two tasting menus. Not sure if that's how it goes or if we were supposed to get a total of four pieces. It was refreshing with the burst of flavor once you bit into it. Didn't really taste the avocado, but it was predominately sour with a nice crunch (3.5/5)

First Course
- Green Peas & Goat Cheese Kulcha, winter truffle - 
Before trying this, I never knew what a kulcha was, but apparently it's like a type of naan. Well, this one was quite tasty with the mix of spices, spicy peas and Goat cheese. Usually, I'm not a fan of goat cheese, but it didn't have a strong cheese flavor. The only thing to complain about was that I wish there was more filling and it was more spread out through the kulcha... (4/5)

Second Course
- Potato Tikki - kale and spinach tempura, sweet and sour mousse, raspberry
This was THE best dish out of the whole menu. The crispy kale and spinach mixed with the mousse was nice a great blend of crunch, and sweetness. I would definitely come back here just for this dish!! (5/5)

- Duck Shikampuri - spiced Huckleberry chutney, pickled radish
Two small round ground duck patties with a small piece of radish. The chutney provided a nice sweetness to the more spiced patties. (3.5/5)

Third Course
- Asparagus Pepper Fry - Podi Masala, spiced cauliflower mousse
There really is nothing special about this dish - just average and nothing to write home about. Just some asparagus with some slight pepper flavoring... (3/5)

- Achari Monkfish - Amaranth Pongal with lemon foam
The lemon foam really didn't do anything to the dish, but the fish was tasty, the sauce was pretty good and the Amaranth (like a type of rice cereal) mixed with the sauce was good as well. It provided a different texture. (3.5/5)

Main Course
- Traditional Butter Chicken - red pepper makhani, fenugreek, butter powder
I was looking forward to this dish, but unfortunately, it was too salty, although the chicken was tender. (2.75/5)

- Beef Short Ribs Curry - baby turnip, rawa & marrow kofta
The short rib was very tender and reminded me of oxtail meat. It's too bad that there really was like only one piece of rib meat. The sauce which tasted like chicken tiki marsala sauce went wonderfully with the rib meat and the rawa (like a mashed potato texture) went well with the sauce as well. In fact, I used up all of my garlic naan in this sauce. The kofta/balled up meat ball was also nicely spiced. (4.5/5)

Accompaniment (you can choose one)
- Garlic Naan - 
Not that much garlic flavor and it wasn't piping hot when we got it, but still good for dipping into the rib sauce. (3.5/5)

Desserts
- Carrot Hawla cake - pistachio kulfi, raisin gel, milk skin crisp
This didn't really taste like a carrot cake. One corner of my cake was a bit too baked and was very crispy. The crisp kind of tastes like a waffle cookie, except crispier. The gel provided a bit more sweetness and the kulfi provided a nice different texture. The cake wasn't too sweet. (3.5/5)

Overall, I would come again, especially to order the potato kulfi.
author: Gilda W.

description:
Love this restaurant! Nice collection of drinks. I have had Mango Mule, Phirdaus and both were good.

I have been here 3 times. All three of them were for lunch, hoping to come back again for their dinner menu. They change their menu often and so I got to taste different items each time.

I had their chicken dish on a uthappam the first time, fish koliwada during second visit and tandoori monk fish salad today. Amazing flavors in the salad- a hint of tangy masala + pickled shallots in the salad brought out unique flavors. 

I had their rose tart(not sure about the name) and cashew cake so far. Loved the rose tart a lot! Cashew cake was okay but accompanying mouse and wild rice wafer were really good. 

I love coming to this restaurant. Will be back again!
author: Priscilla P.

description:
I made an online reservation here and arrived on time. When we walked in we were told it would be about 20 minutes for our table. The bar looked pretty cool so we decided to decided to grab a drink. They had a great selection of fun drinks. 

When we were seated it took awhile for anyone to come over to our table. We were beginning to wonder if the waitstaff has been told we had been seated. 

When we were ready to order we asked if the menu could be wine paired. They had an in house sommelier so we didn't think it would be a problem. It wasn't, but it was odd because when he poured each glass he poured one glass for the both of us to share. I would have expected a glass or half a glass each, but it didn't go that way. It was surprising for a fancy restaurant. Also, all the wines were poured at the same time so the whites got a little room temperature by the time the course came out. My husband and I exchanged a look, but just went with it. As we progressed through the meal we asked for a little extra of one of the wines as we were running low. The sommelier told us we had interchanged the wines with the courses. My husband and I both remembered the order. I may not have a great memory, but my husband remembers everything and he agreed with the order I restated. 

That's how the wine went. As for the dishes. We ordered a couple of small plates and a couple of large ones. We got the chili paneer, chicken 65, lamb chop, and sea bass. We've been to other Indian fusion restaurants in the area and the flavors did not pop for me at this restaurant. The menu and decor was amazingly similar to another Indian fusion restaurant that had opened at about the same time, but I don't think they did as good of a job at this restaurant.
author: Payal V.

description:
This place served a unique combination of flavors in all their dishes. Every indian dish was served with a twist and a great presentation.

Most recommended dishes:
- potato tikki with kale salad
- vegetable quinoa-wild rice pulao
- pinwheel paneer

The portions are small, and can be shared between two.
author: Shraddha N.

description:
Rooh takes care of the finer details of fine dining by ensuring that they provide both a quality meal and experience.  The tableware is beautiful (seriously, order some tea or look at some of the Yelp photos).  The waitstaff is very professional and was patient with answering any questions or requests that we had.

The portions are rather small by my standards so it if you eat larger portions, it may take more than a single dish to sate your hunger.  It's easy to set up for family style here.  Personally, I rather enjoyed the butter chicken, cauliflower dish, sampler, and a pot of chai or green tea.
author: Justin L.

description:
Another work celebration of a successful project at a nice restaurant, but this time my review isn't a year late.  It's only half a year late!  This time, we went to Rooh, a high end Indian restaurant, serving "modern Indian fare made with California elements" and had a pre-selected menu:

Canapes
- Malai Broccoli and Sweet Potato Skewer
- Prawn Malabar Sausage, Chili Mayonnaise

Salads/Small Plates
- Potato Tikki, Kale & Spinach Tempura, Sweet & Sour Yogurt Mousse, Raspberry
- Tuna Bhel, Avocado, Tamarind Gel, Puffed Black Rice, Baby Radish, Togarashi
- Kashmiri Lamb Ribs, Apricot & Chili Marmalade, Radish & Yogurt Chutney

Main Course
- Fish Amritsari, Cilantro and Mint Chutney, Lemon Mayonnaise, Salad, Potato Wedges
- Asparagus & Grain Pulao, Cashew, Crispy Onion, Avocado & Yogurt Raita
- Butter Chicken, Red Pepper Makhani, Fenugreek & Butter Powder

Accompaniments
- Saffron Rice, Garlic Naan, Avocado and Garlic Raita

Dessert
- Tutti Frutti Cassata, Vanilla Sponge, Compressed Strawberry, Honeycomb
- Chocolate Pave, Masala Chai Ice Cream, Hazelnut Chikki, Cocoa Crisp

The highlights for me were the Potato Tikki and Tuna Bhel, while the lowlights were the Pulao and Lamb Ribs.  Everything else was just kind of there and not memorable. Everything had very familiar Indian flavors, but each dish usually had a "California" element thrown in.  For example, the bhel puri had tuna, the pulao was made of grains instead of rice, the potato tikki had kale, and there was plenty of avocado thrown in.

While the California concept was interesting, I'm not sure it really added anything to the food.  For me, what shone through was the Indian flavors and not the California additions. So, in essence, Rooh is a place you'd go to if you want a high end restaurant with good Indian food.
author: Nadeem A.

description: We were excited to try this place as we had been hearing about it for a long time. Finding a reservation on a Saturday was not easy. We were promptly seated as soon as we arrived. Love the cocktails. I had a vodka melon drink which was really good. We had a couple of small plates - dahi Puri, califlower koliwada, scallops and chicken Malai kofta. Loved all of them except for the murg Malai kofta. Found it too cheesy. For dinner, we went for the butter chicken and the monk fish in Amritsar khichdi. Loved the chicken and found the fish okay. So overall an okay experience for the taste buds. Some dishes were a hit and some were a miss. The service was definitely superb. I would love to go back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Lisa H.

description:
A modern Indian dining with chic interior design and creative cocktails. Service was excellent! The food was a mix of typical Indian dishes dish with a twist and inventive dishes with modern preparation and presentation. 

For appetizers, we tried the chicken65, lamb ribs and pork belly. All three dishes were delicious. The chicken was a bit spicy with a hint of curry taste. The lamb ribs were awesome; it was nicely charred on the outside and fell off the bone with sweet and spicy glaze. The pork belly was great too; it was cooked just right; tender with a tangy flavor. 

For the main entree, we tried the butter chicken, short ribs curry and lamb shank. The butter chicken was great; the chicken was tender and tasty, the sauce had enough heat and spice. The short ribs curry was delicious too. The short ribs were cooked to perfection and the curry sauce was creamy and flavorful. The lamb shank was good, but I was a bit underwhelmed by the flavor. I wanted more heat and spice from this dish.
author: Sam M.

description: Nice classy experience for indian food.. i like that they are expanding indian food beyond the regular. I went here for my birthday and had a good time..
author: Neha B.

description:
I've only been here once but I'm a huge fan and have been recommending Rooh to anyone looking for a good spot to eat in the city. 

They've done a great job elevating Indian food without being pretentious or losing the authentic Indian flavors in each dish. The decor inside the restaurant is beautiful and it's great for a nice meal out without breaking the bank.

If you're a fan of chaat (or just don't know what to try) the potato tikki and pani puri are both a must. The passionfruit water that goes with the pani puri is amazing! So creative. 

They also do a bottomless mimosa brunch on the weekends if you're into that. 

Service was great and the food even better; I'll definitely be back!
author: Renu A.

description:
The 2nd visit to dinner was a feast..!!
Excellent service and delicious food like previous visit.

Ordered the following items
Crispy Papad with 3 Chutneys  -- I liked the Sweet chutney so much.

Appetizers
Chicken 65 -- Unlike the typical chicken 65, which comes only with meat, this dish has chicken on top of uttapam, sour cream and other items
Keema Hyderabadi  -- Minced lamb cooked to perfection.The bread that came along with it was awesome.

Main Dishes
Butter Chicken -- Good
Garlic Naan -- Didn't eat.
Tandoori Roti -- Bread cooked in tandoori oven. Delicious
Jackfruit Dumplings -- Tasted like falafel but delicious.
Grain Pulao -- This is more like a health conscious pulao where quinoa is used instead of rice along with other vegetables like artichoke. Also raita contains avocado.

Desserts -- Ordered all the desserts in the menu..!!
Chocolate Cake -- This was my favorite.
Halwa cake -- Carrot cake served with cardamom flavored ice cream and other items.
Mango Malai Tart -- Similar to mango mousse.
Attached photos
author: Krishna M.

description: I had been here for their valentines day tasting menu. Nothing to complain of the food and the service was really good! If a vegetarian you should definitely try their paneer pinwheel. Tad bit on the expensive side however worth it. Our bill was 250$ for 2
author: Prajakta P.

description:
This is a great spot, a bit overpriced though! I mean the items were quality and the space was also great.

I'm not sure if I go back though as I don't think the higher prices really worth it:
author: Jay G.

description:
Rooh is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. They are doing some of the most inventive stuff I've seen with Indian food in a looong time. I love going there for a celebratory meal or a happy hour cocktail and appetizers. Don't miss the kulchas and keema!

My husband and I love Rooh so much that we asked them to cater our wedding reception. Folks at the event couldn't stop talking about how incredible their food was. The prawn and fish koliwada was a HUGE hit and so was the dahi poori. 

These guys are doing amazing things. Go celebrate something special with them!
author: Saad A.

description:
Gathered here for two work events, and was pleasantly surprised that they were able to accommodate our large party on such short notice.

While it's not traditional Indian food, everything we ordered tasted great!

Staff were extremely attentive, dishes always cleared when empty and drink glasses always full.

--

Only negative is that for lunch my coworker paying the bill asked if the tip was included. Our server said only part of it was included... They added a 20% tip, which is earned when you're as attentive as they were but c'mon... That's misleading. If you're already adding more than 18% and a customer asks if it's included, say yes. Thankfully our party saw it but when you're paying for tax, SF mandate and a 20% tip, don't tell us it's only a 'partial tip added.' 

Hopefully management will correct this server and train future servers about this.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Pro tip: Order their chai milk tea, it comes with a matching tea pot and tea set. Also they have amazing looking cocktails! 
Keep in mind: The food can be a bit spicy so make sure you ask the staff to make accommodations if you're sensitive. 
Instagrammable: Yes, absolutely. The food has very vibrant but sometimes what you see on the restaurant Instagram account doesn't always look like the food you get in the restaurant. Set your expectations but nevertheless it's still pretty. 
Atmosphere: Very posh and cool.
author: Christina K.

description:
Feel as I walk in a palace of all beautiful things, charming, beautiful and inviting. All the color and things that this girl love, green, blue, pink, velvet Bordeaux, all thing silks, especially those pillows!

Such a romantic spot, takes my breathe away! High ceiling, floating curtains, art works on the wall, that seafoam chairs, comfy couch, I never want to leave! 

This is a place I can dress up and feels like a princess!! Forget this hipster SF, that's so not me! Bring back the glamour, respect yourself, respect the chef, respect the Somm, and respect the company you are with.

The charming Sommelier Jeffrey, he is knowledgeable and know what I want! And that infamous chef from Mumbai to Dubai, Sujan Sarkar, amazingly talented. 

We love every single dish. The Chicken was so good. The lamb chop was my favorite. The Sampler is a must order. The creativity of the foods here changed the way you think of Indian Cuisine.

I really love it here and can't wait to come back with my loved ones.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
We had a good anniversary dinner here - tasty dishes and pleasant service in an upscale, modern atmosphere.

My husband and I shared the following dishes (it was too much food - we had to pack leftovers and didn't have room for dessert):

1) Potato tikki- quite good, the tiki was flavorful and the kale fritters completed the dish
2) Lamb Keema with "Pau" bread - flavorful but rich; the Keema was well seasoned  
3) Chicken 65 - tasty, with a unique presentation with the chicken on an uttapam
4) Nihari lamb shank - good
5) Short ribs - Rich but delicious (my favorite dish)
6) Garlic Naan - good, but pretty standard 

We were a bit disappointed to not see on the menu some of the dishes we had read so much about in past reviews (e.g. pani puri, jhalmuri).

Our waiter was friendly and helpful.  The food came out promptly and the presentation was lovely.

The modern, upscale ambiance was nice, and the Hindi pop music playing on the speakers made for a fun, inviting atmosphere.

Overall, a good spot for a special occasion dinner.  Everything was solid, though we weren't blown away.
author: Barnali D.

description: Loved our dinner here! Food was amazing and so beautifully presented. They also have an extensive wine and spirits list, as well as a clever cocktail menu. Love the idea of sharing a bunch of small plates  get the scallops - the corn curry sauce they sit in is so good  and be sure to save room for dessert, the coconut brioche one  is amazing!
author: Weich Y.

description:
4,5 stars really. I've been eating A LOT of awesome Indian food lately so I might be too spoiled. They have tweaked certain dishes and are well on their way to being perfect. 

The restaurant is beautifully designed. From the walls to the pillows to the teacups, it's colorful, luxurious and pretty.

Good service. Even when it is busy, it does not feel busy. 

The presentation of their food is incredible. The dishes are like small masterpieces. 

The food itself ranges from good to great to excellent. The first time we visited, we did the tasting menu and the appetizers really stood out to me. We had the same experience this time. 
Their Dahi Puri was amazing. It was an explosion of textures and spices. They made some changes to the Paneer Pinwheel and it paid off. While it fell a bit short during our first visit, it was spot on this time.
My aubergine in peanut sauce (forgot the official name) was good but lacked that extra element to it. It was too much of the same taste, too soon. While I love peanut, it was quite overpowering. 

Last time we tried their cocktails and I would definitely recommend them, even though they're not cheap. This time I tried the Mistletoe Kisses Tea and it was great. Their teapot and teacup were so stylish, I wish I had them at home.
author: Ellen H.

description:
After being somewhat let-down by August One Five, I was a little trepidatious going to another high-end Indian place. Fortunately, Rooh exceeded all expectations and truly earned its 5 stars. 
My wife and I came in about 30 minutes early for our reservation and were okay with going to the bar, but our table was ready! We ordered a drink- I had the berry shikanji, which was just okay, and she had the Kerala, which was good but a little sweet. Our friends came and we started with the chutney sampler, which came with a sweet tomato based chutney, a green chutney, and a traditional chutney- all of which were fantastic. I also had the whiskey drink that came with a curry leaf (I forget the name) and my wife had the pink one, which was perfect. 
For small plates, we shared the scallop, the cauliflower, the pork belly, and the burrata. The scallop was perfectly cooked and the sauce was fantastic. The cauliflower was a take on Manchurian and was just different enough than the original to be unique. The burrata was good, but nothing too special- same with the pork belly, which was a little sweet.
For dinner, I had the tandoori monkfish, my wife had the paneer pinwheels, our friends had the seabass and the jackfruit dumplings, respectively. The tandoori monkfish was fantastic, it's been years since I had monkfish and it did not disappoint. The paneer pinwheels came in a makhani type sauce that's probably the best I've had, ever. The jackfruit came in a similar sauce.
For dessert, we had the chocolate pave and the carrot halwa, which was more like a carrot cake that was sumptuous. The ice cream that came with it was dense, a little more like a kulfi and heavily cardamom-flavored. The pave was good, too.

Service was a *little* rushed, as I'm sure they were trying to turn the table, but overall was really good. I definitely recommend this place and you should go here!
author: Samir K.

description:
Hands down the best Indian lunch / brunch food I've ever had! 

We sat outside and although it was in the shade, we enjoyed the somewhat warmer weather.  

Our server Ashley was super helpful with making recommendations.   

I knew this place was going to be special because SF eater named it one of the top brunch spots.  Although I was a little hesitant to try it knowing how heavy indian food can be... they really had some delicious and innovative dishes. 

We started with the pani poori - hellz yeah!  This dish was like a little explosion of indian flavors and I couldn't stop eating them.

The kale and potato salad was interesting.  Definitely had the Indian influence but with a kale twist.  I enjoyed it but try not to eat a ton of fried food.

My main course was the tuna avocado.  Yes. To. All. Of. It.

Totally not a typical Indian dish but I inhaled that dish.

I can't wait to go back for the tasting menu!
author: Kimberly L.

description: A friend recommended this place and I'm so glad she did!  What a fun and funky non-traditional Indian restaurant. Fabulous cocktail menu and the food was delicious!  We shared dishes, which was great so that everyone got to try. We started with the pork belly, gunpowder scallop, tomato and burrata, and potato tikki.  For mains we went with the short rib curry and butter chicken. Both were yummy, but the butter chicken was to die for.  We are definitely going back to try more!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I don't go often to Indian restaurant since I'm not really fan of Indian food. I think this restaurant might change my mind. The food was amazing, share platters like tuna bhel, baked oysters, potato tikki was so tasty. We ordered traditional butter chicken, sea bass, lamb shank, beef short ribs curry, and all was so good, no complains. The naan is the best. ;-)
Environment was nice, quiet, and service was superb. It was pleasant dinner.
author: Galina M.

description: Most Authentic Indian food, cant get over the taste . Both vegetarian and non-vegetarian food tastes delicious. Dahi puri was the highlight of the meal with perfect amount of spice. Definitely a must try appetizer.
author: Siddhi P.

description: Service was horrendous! One of those restaurants you ask and ask and ask and they simply don't get it. Food was tasty but the stomach ache later pretty much stole the show. I can't recommend this place, they've simply missed.
author: Andrew S.

description:
We went to Rooh for valentine's day dinner. Below are the pros and cons.

Pros
- really nice and romantic ambiance
- great cocktails
- friendly staff
- lobster and mushroom main dishes were extremely delicious
- great options for vegetarians

Cons
- price (it costs around 300 bucks for 2 people dinner)
- some of the food we tried was average at best: paneer roll and soup were ok but I tried much better in way cheaper Indian restaurants
- tough luck to vegans: I didn't see anything vegan on the menu (might be different on normal dinner menu)
author: Sevda G.

description: We had a reservation and were seated immediately. The butter chicken was amazing but took a while to arrive. The waitress told us that the butter chicken serves 3 but I think it's fine to order 1 per person. I usually eat an average amount and was able to finish one on my own. Definitely the best butter chicken I've ever had.  We also ordered the tikki as a appetizer which was really good.  The cashew cake with thandai ice cream was really tasty!!
author: Sherman C.

description:
Can I just lick the sauce? Really, that's all I want to know!!

All kidding aside had an awesome lunch at ROOH recently. It was a special occasion and of course, we had to celebrate in the city. ROOH was at the top of our list of restaurants to try and it was a complete success! There was plenty of metered street parking, the restaurant's ambiance was modern and lively, and customer service was on point from start to finish (shout out to Ashley!!).

Their lunch menu is much shorter than dinner, but there were still a lot of dishes to choose from. And honestly, if I wasn't afraid to "mix" I probably would've had a ball trying a number of cocktails from their drinks menu (but limited myself to 2).

Aside from drinks, we shared everything...

Non-vegetarian platter | An absolute must have! The only difference between this and the vegetarian version is 1 dish, the chicken cooked in onion, where the vegetarian platter serves paneer cooked in onion instead. The platter was a healthy serving of various dishes mainly to be eaten with rice or naan. I was completely blown away by the yellow dal! Just absolute heaven! I almost didn't want to share anymore.

Chicken 65 | A spicy chicken dish served with sour cream and dolled up with thinly sliced radish and micro greens. The chicken was tender and reminded me of grilled chicken nuggets in sauce (but the prettier, fancier type). Make sure to have a bite with the sour cream to cool things down.

Tutti Frutti Cassata | A soft creamy cake garnished with strawberries and blood orange compote (sauce) and little chunks of sweet honey comb(?). Light and a little tart. Sorry, we got carried away and forgot to snap a picture.

I would come back just for the yellow dal and will HAVE TO give dinner a try next time. ROOH's Indian food is definitely elevated and if you're into Indian food or trying new cuisine, make a reservation. You won't be disappointed!
author: Maricel S.

description:
Far exceeded expectations. The ground lamb small plate was perfectly seasoned and delicious, and the chicken was surprisingly tender and moist. 

Service: very attentive and courteous. 

Don't forget to try their tea at the end of the meal, in lieu of coffee. It balances the palate perfectly.
author: Kristen S.

description:
Rooh is excellent in every way, serving up Indian cuisine and cocktails in a truly innovative fashion! 

The ambiance at Rooh is very chic and upscale, without being pretentious - perfect for celebrations, work dinners, and date nights, with that nice Indian touch. 

Service was top notch and attentive (I accidentally dropped my fork and it was immediately picked up and replaced - part of me wishes I was on the Michelin team doing that for a living haha). The server was eager to recommend his favorite dishes and very friendly.

We started out by ordering cocktails after a chef at Frontier Space in Pleasanton recommended Rooh for just that. I ordered the Filter Kafi cocktail and just LOVED it. I didn't get much of the coffee flavoring, but it was loaded with cardamom and spices and placed a unique Indian spin on a vodka-based cocktail. My friend got the Chai Punch which was also delicious, with hints of Assam tea. I love how their cocktail menu breaks down cocktails based on flavor profile: sweet, sour, salty, bitter, etc. Very innovative here.

For food, we ordered the Lamb Keema small plate as an appetizer and the Butter Chicken as our main. 

Lamb Keema: The Keema was simply outstanding! It was flavored so so well, and a perfectly rich testament to the Keema we make at home, with the minced lamb cooked really well. I would highly highly recommend this dish and it was also sizeable for an appetizer. I will be dreaming about this one - easily the best Keema I've ever had. 

Butter Chicken: We were apprehensive ordering Butter Chicken because it's just such a standard dish normally, and we wondered how Rooh specifically would elevate it. But, it was really good and frankly I found it less creamy than at other Indian restaurants with still loads of flavor packed in. This is an easy dish to love. Most places serve it with really dry chicken, hoping the cream and gravy will balance it out. But at Rooh, the chicken in this dish was moist and perfectly cooked and so while there wasn't an added flare, it is still a very solid Butter Chicken.

I can't wait to come back to Rooh and try more of their dishes and cocktails!
author: Sabina S.

description: IMPRESSIVE! Food flavors, decor, ambiance, menu creativity and service. Bravo, ROOH, we loved every bite and will be back!
author: Anna C.

description:
So sad to see the recent changes at Rooh.  This spot is right by our work, beautiful venue, food and drinks were excellent. 

However, the last time we came back, the menu was completely different, both food and drinks.  

We ordered a few dishes and the flavor was horrible.  They also didn't have any naan that day and the tandoori oven was broken so no tandoori food. 

The Asian waitress lady was really weird as well.  We ordered the cauliflower appetizer and she gave us chicken.  I'm a new vegetarian, but I would feel bad for those that are die hard.  Instead of apologizing or bringing us the right order, she just said we had too much food already so probably didn't need the cauliflower right?  Another waitress saw and brought us the cauliflower, which was actually a lot better than the chicken ....and especially because we already had butter chicken it was an overkill.  

Not sure if the chef changed or if it was an offday.
author: Vi Y.

description: I honestly cannot remember how I found out about this place, but feel so happy and grateful that I did! My team and I came here for a dinner whilst in the Bay Area for a conference. I have never seen such a unique cocktail menu and will not spoil the surprise of how it looks. Our server, Patty, did a phenomenal job taking care of us, including catering to my vegan requests and treating our team member with a birthday to a piece of chocolate cake with a candle! Dishes that stood out to me were the chickpea cake, which came with the most amazing sauce, the vegetables in the grain pulao and the poppadum with sauces. My only complaint is that they were out of the only vegan dessert option, which sounded delightful. The ambiance here was beautiful and I would definitely recommend it for a special dinner!
author: Jana B.

description:
We booked a table for 12 people for my friends wedding party on a Monday night. Ordered but veg and non veg starters and main course. The potion sizes were small, which was fine but the waiter who was assigned to asked only one person to place the order. Considering it is a high end restaurant, the service should be convenient to the customer and not the restaurant staff. We did not have a great experience with the service and the food was rather okay. Paneer and Dal makhni were good but nothing too great. The food lacked flavour. 
The thing that ruined my experience was when the waiter asked us to return a old fashion small empty bottle that my friend picked up as a remembrance for her wedding dinner. Even after telling him that we wanted it as a token of memory he refused to give it, that felt very cheap on the staff part. We paid for the drink so I don't no why they had to be so ride about a small bottle. Don't think I'll go back.
author: Samhita R.

description: A twist on Indian food that I never would have thought of. The presentation of each dish takes it up a notch, but that doesn't take away from how flavorful each bite is. I got the lamb shank nihari that was tremendous. Each piece of lamb fell right off the bone and seemingly dissolved in my mouth immediately. All of the appetizers were great as well. For someone who doesn't usually enjoy SF, ROOH gives me a reason to want to make the trek up from the South Bay. Writing this review is making my mouth water!
author: Varun K.

description:
Great Indian fusion food with Good Ambiance. 4.5 stars for sure. 

Been to this place multiple times with visiting family and friends from far and near. This is definitely a place that you can take to impress others about the Indian fine dining scene in SF, as they have good attention to detail and they are trying to create some unique flavors. 

From the various things that we have tried over multiple times, here is what I would recommend to order: 
Appetizers: 
Veg: Dahi Puri: very refreshing, good to get things started with a mouthful of flavor
Veg: Paneer Chili: this one has multiple levels of taste. It is not just one piece of Paneer that is wrapped in fried vermicelli along with three chutneys.. it can have multiple flavors based on the combination of chutneys you go for
Veg: Potato Tikki: nice fried kale and spinach salad with chutneys along with a tasty potato tikki in the center... very nice
Non-Veg: Keema Hyderabadi: MUST ORDER!!... of all the food that I have had here this is my favorite. Very well cooked and flavored... have it while it is warm and order an extra Buttered Pao with it, you will need it.
Non-Veg: Baked Chicken Malai Tikka: very flavorful and I loved the nearly burnt garlic on top... 
Non-Veg: Tuna Bhel: Very refreshing and a good take on an Indian classic.. enjoy it if you like fish
Non-Veg: Chicken 65: This is also part of my usual order here and is always very tasty.. 

As you can see I love the appetizers at this place and they are totally worth it. The main course if also good but I usually order the greatest hits here:
Dal Makhani: This is very nice Dal. Many of my friends say that it reminds them of home cooked good dal... which is always a very big complement to indian food
