Fried cauliflower appetizer with excellent sauces, a potato donut thing too hard to describe, full of interesting spices and a sauce, a chickpea cake entree that had a sauce with depth.  We loved all three dishes.

I have had better naan.Very good brownie and ice cream dessert dish though would explore dessert menu further next time as we will certainly be back.
author: Che S.

description:
I really can't think of enough good things to say about ROOH.   Dined there last night and was blown away.   I was really excited when high-end Indian started to take hold in the bay area, but generally have been somewhat underwhelmed.   I have eaten at Juhu Beach Club, Rasa, Babu Ji and August 1 Five (not Campton Place....yet), but ROOH, hands down, rises to the top of the heap.   

I won't go into detail about every dish, as we each ordered the tasting menu (recommended) and we each ordered a different option in each category and shared.

- Ambiance:   very colorful, very luxurious, not overly loud.   Perfect mix of hip, luxury and fun.   

- Service:   very friendly, very knowledgeable.   We were gushing about the meal to our server at the end, and she brought the chef out to talk to us.   He explained to us how he executed his concept and how he was able to extract so much flavor out of ingredients and still keep the flavors very indian despite not being able to use certain cooking techniques here in the states.

- Cocktails:   Amazing!   The glasses and vessels used were beyond elegant....I kind of wanted to steal them all.   The tumeric tonic is probably the best cocktail I have had all year.

- Food:   Everything was delicious.   Flavor was on point every single time.   All of the curry sauces were the best I have had.  The proteins were cooked to perfection.   Every vegetable was crisp and the flavor was allowed to shine through despite the spices.   Nothing was over or underseasoned.   The mushrooms were incredible.   The canapes in the beginning were all very different and fun and unique (I the egg foam thing served in the egg shell was my favorite).  The desserts were great.....best carrot cake I have ever had.   The only gripes I had were that there were a few things that were a little hard to eat.   They served this rice puff bar thing with avocado on it, and when we went to cut it with the fork, both of our flew off the plate.   Also, on the chocolate dessert, there was this compressed ice cream log thing on the side, that was either a little too compressed or a little too frozen so, again, was difficult to cut with a fork.

Overall, this is the best Indian food I have ever had in my life, and is probably my new favorite restaurant.   If you love Indian food, come here.   If you don't love Indian food, come here.   Honestly, I don't know what there is to not like here.   I would be very surprised if this place doesn't get a Michelin star during the next round.
author: Christian C.

description: Our server was extremely accommodating and kind. Every thing on the table was mouth watering and had the perfect aroma. Starters were delicious. Highlight was the black daal on the side and kulcha platters. Will visit again when in the city.
author: Anushree S.

description:
Went to explore this Indian-fusion place and the food did not disappoint! When we walked into the restaurant we noticed the cool decor and music. It was pretty loud and crowded for a Thursday evening. We were promptly seated and began to look at the menu. Our server was awesome and gave us some hints on their specialty cocktail menu. It was creative and broken down into palate (sweet, salty, astringent, etc). I do not remember the names of the cocktails, but I had one with bourbon (astringent) and it was quite good and also a tequila drink that was also good. 

We opted to sample some shared plates (plus a few sent out from the chef with his compliments) and started with the shared combination appetizer plate. We then had lamb ribs, cumin potatoes, chickpeas, pork belly, kale tempura with a potato cake and a few others. The sizes were perfect for sharing and getting a sample of the food. I was very impressed with the originality of the seasoning and created excitement for Indian food. Nothing was spicy at all. In fact, some spiciness would be an asset. Overall, quite good. The pork belly tasted more Asian than Indian, but pretty good. 

My only complaint would be that it took forever to get our drinks. Like look at your watch kind of long. Also, the food came out in two bursts with the appetizer and 3 items at once, then almost 20 minutes later for the rest of the items and by that time we were pretty full so needed to take some home. This, I am sure, will get worked out in time as the place is very new. 

Overall, exciting flavors and great service (albeit slow) and once they get their service smoothed out, this place will truly come into it's own, and we will definately be back for that!
author: Lorenzo R.

description: Went here for a work team lunch. This is one of the few Indian restaurants in San Francisco which actually has good Indian food (in my opinion). We got 2 menu options for our event. We went with the simple, more traditional option (although I really wanted to try the 2nd option which had a lot of interesting fusion dishes - like masala chai ice cream, avocado and garlic raita!! :O ). 5 stars for the food, service, interior and ambience. The desert was a bit disappointing so I took 1 star off.
author: Lasya B.

description:
I am surprised this place is not rated higher. We had a fabulous meal here the other night. If you couple the wonderful service with the creative food, we had a meal we hope to enjoy again and again.

We are garlic naan fans, so ordered the garlic naan with assorted chutneys. They were varied from the spicy to the cooling. Each was individual; each was very good. The lamb ribs with apricot glaze was tender and flavorful. The glaze complimented, but did not hide the good lamb flavor. We had an asparagus pepper fry. The sauce was a cauliflower chutney mousse that highlighted the asparagus. It came with a dosa crisp made from cauliflower that surprised with its subtlety. We finished with lamb chop with pistachios. The meat was warn and tender. The flavor was divine. What impressed us the most was the tenderness of the meat and how well each sauce complimented, but did not overwhelm what it accompanied.

We ordered wine by the glass. They have good, not ordinary wines by the glass. More restaurants should learn that trick. The wine list was varied with prices for many price points. We were impressed.

Finally, the service was wonderful. Our server was attentive.  She knew her wines. She had able backup. There was one slip that was corrected without question immediately. We felt welcome. The restaurant had a comfortable buzz.  We tipped generously.
author: Ronald A.

description:
Ambiance - the best part of this restaurant. 

Food - Rooh has an interesting take on authentic Indian food, bringing together amazing flavors. The food and drinks are innovative and tasteful. See pictures. 

Service - inconsistent. Sometimes it's incredible and other times it's uninspiring. 

Reason for 2 stars - 

1. I would watch out for the undeclared 20% gratuity fee that is automatically add to your check regardless of the party size. We were only a party of four and didn't realize they did this - we've definitely added a tip in addition to the full amount in our prior visits to Rooh so I feel like it's sneaky to do this without informing customers. And especially when the party size is 4. 

2. Reservations are difficult to make as they don't pick up the phone half the time. We've been asked once to leave the table while waiting for our Uber because the next party arrived. They need to work on their reservation system.
author: Mounica B.

description: Came here for lunch with a large group and paid $27 (including tax and tip) for a small butter chicken + rice entree. It tasted good, but gosh the small serving sizes and prices are not worth it. I left so hungry that I immediately ate another meal after lunch here. I'll need two or three entrees from this place to get full. I wouldn't recommend this place if you're hungry, but this is a fine, classy spot if you work in soma and can expense this meal lol.
author: Annie S.

description:
The appetizers were delicious! I loved malai chicken and cauliflower 65. Garlic naan was soooo soft.
Please try mango mule cocktail and in desserts, carrot halwa cake will finish off your dinner with a bang!
I am definitely going to be a regular at this classic upscale Indian restaurant!
author: Zeal V.

description:
Where do I even begin... this is by far the best "Progressive" Indian restaurant I have ever tried in the state of California.

Pro Tip: go here for a date with your special someone. 

Cocktails: carefully crafted and cover spices from almost every region of India. My personal favorite is Patna fizz only because I was born in Patna and love Gin. 

All their Entrees are amazing ... yes I said all because I have tried all of them by now. Even the butter chicken which may sound very traditional tastes way better than your fav Indian restaurant dish. Appetizers are definitely progressive and I recommend trying the lamb, tuna.
author: Adi R.

description: I really, really wanted to like this place! I'm sad that it was kind of a disappointing experience. The portions were super tiny, everything was overpriced, and the service was slow... they had also forgotten about one of our dishes until we asked about it. Our server was really friendly and apologetic about it though. Each dish had a unique twist of flavors, and it was definitely a fusion cuisine--but I didn't feel like the prices were justified. If you're craving authentic, straight-up Indian food, then this probably isn't the place. I think I'll stick to the Indian restaurants in the tenderloin.
author: Rie U.

description: The food is really good here. The thing that I love here is that every dish tastes different and had a unique flavor. I loved their drinks too especially the one with curry leaves. Yes, it sounds weird, but it tasted awesome. The only reason I'm docking of points is that I felt the service was okay.  I'd a mishap where the bill posted on my card was higher than what I'd signed for. However, once I wrote a review, the owner was very considerate, apologized for the mistake and credited my account back the overcharged amount.
author: Shrihari K.

description:
Amazing all around. The food, decor, service - truly remarkable!

We came back 3 times already and it just keeps getting better. Marija at the front is the nicest, friendliest, hostess we've met in any SF restaurant.

Highly recommend this place for anyone looking for high-end fusion Indian food that stays true to its origins
author: Nadav S.

description: Very good, nice decor and delicious higher end Indian food. Tried butter chicken and lamb shank and both were great!
author: Joe S.

description: Always on the search for upscale indian food, and I was happy with my experience at ROOH. Although it isn't the best I've had, it's worthy of a try and my 4-star rating!
author: Asmita J.

description:
I loved almost everything. I had the potato tikki and liked that a lot. The naan bread was good, but I felt it needed a tad bit of salt. I also ordered the butter chicken which was yummy. I decided to give their carrot cake dessert a try, but it didn't hit the spot for me regarding sweetness and overall flavor. It was a bit awkward to eat as well.

5 stars for my server! He was nice, attentive, helpful and extremely knowledgeable. I could tell he's been in the service industry for a while and he was amazing! The other restaurant staff are great as well. I miss the kind of service that Rooh offers. I hope other diners appreciate it as much as I do. You get a real dining experience here. I will most definitely be back. Thank you!! 

Suggestion to the restaurant: 

How about adding chai tiramisu to the dessert menu? Mmm...
author: Angela V.

description:
I really enjoyed the food here, and am surprised by the reviews.  This is a high end Indian restaurant, so expect to pay like any other SOMA upscale establishment.  The atmosphere is modern, beautiful bar and modern decor.  The presentation is nice, they take the time to put the ingredients forward, it's not the usual takeout Indian.

We walked in after a happy hour on a Friday, were seated promptly and had very attentive and knowledgeable servers.  The only thing I would recommend is spacing the food, we shared 4 appetizers and they all came out at the same time, I would have enjoyed a meal that was a few courses.  

The food: 

Chutney Sampler with Papad: the sauces were great, and the papad was crispy and absolutely not oily, nice start to any meal to wake up your taste buds. 

Charred Sweet Potato: The flavors were bold, well executed and cooked just right.  You can have it by itself or order it as a side to an entire. 

Keema Haderabi: this was interesting and we did't really know what we would get, it was a nice flavor, more the Indian type texture of sauce you'd expect but again not heavy, you can see and taste the ingredients.

Crispy Lamb Ribs: great sharing portion, we had 2 each, the meat was falling off the bone, no fat, great flavor.  

While we were plenty full from this meal, I liked sharing small dishes and trying various things rather than committing to a main course. The portions are generous.  I will definitely want to come back and try more dishes, nice Indian places are not easy to find in the city, we only have a few and this one is definitely playing with the food and new concepts.
author: Inga W.

description:
Woah! I've never had fancy Indian food before and this was delicious! My table tried a variety of dishes and they were all fantastic. I really enjoyed the sea bass, and some of the small plates we ordered (one was a raw tuna dish and the other was a spinach tempura dish? I can't remember) 

I also really enjoyed the pink city cocktail. As the waitress said, it definitely has some personality! I believe it was tequila with guava purée and some chile, garnished with a spicy cucumber. Very interesting and delicious with a kick!

The service was fantastic. Beautiful food presentation, not pushy about ordering food (as a different review said), constantly refilled my water glass, and honest about food/drink recommendations (I asked for drink recs and she said she recommended staying away from a particular drink because the kitchen was re-working the recipe and I appreciated that tip!)

Additionally, I came here for a work dinner so I didn't personally pay for this meal, so I didn't pay attention to food/service value for the money you pay!


Overall very tasty, unique and flavorful food with great service. Check it out!
author: Claire D.

description:
The space is lovely and the service is attentive, friendly and knowledgeable. And the cocktails are fantastic! 

Some of the food is very tasty, but the vegetarian food is just too sweet and jammy for me. After appetizers, I felt like I'd eaten 3 tablespoons of jam. It's a shame- I feel like they've Americanized the food too much, and lost some of the fresh, spicy, earthy and bitter flavors in Indian food. The chickpea cakes were really heavy and mushy, but the sauce was delicious. 

I'd come back for the cocktails, and maybe try some other menu items.
author: Ari W.

description: If you have a food allergy or are vegan, do not come here. There were only 3 things without dairy on the menu and only 1 was vegan. Even the rice has dairy. As someone who is allergic to dairy, it was the worst restaurant for dairy I have ever been to. The waiter was knowledgeable about the few things I could order but seemed unapologetic and not accommodating. The tuna chaat was tasty but I will never go back. I don't expect everything to be dairy free but at least a couple of things and rice seems reasonable to have dairy free.
author: Becky T.

description:
Small portions, big flavor.

At first we had crinkled eyebrows because it looked like they were skimping. But it was plenty, once we ordered some rice, and one more serving of the delicious garlic naan.

It's kind of annoying to me when I go to a restaurant, order curry, or something like that, neglect to order rice, then have the server act surprised that I want rice to along with my spicy curry. Anyway, I went through that routine here.

Don't get me wrong. The servers were fine. They brought exactly what I ordered. It's just that it's kind of nice when a server can anticipate that you may, potentially, want rice with your curry.

Enough of that. Let's talk about quality. In a word: excellent! It was a perfect blend of spice and heat.

I'd highly recommend Rooh for lunch!
author: Greg J.

description: Came here for dinner to celebrate a work promotion for my better half and they went above and beyond! Had a card waiting for us at the table and the food was beyond delicious! Service was perfect! Will be back - i live a block away hahaha
author: Alexis G.

description:
+'s
1) Prawn sausage from the assorted sampler. V tasty. Recommend the sampler. 
2) potato tikki -- must try
3) lamb shank was super soft and tender BUT tad on the salty side
4) Delhi 6 (cocktail)
5) gajar halwa cake
6) general ambience


-'s:
1) our server (a bit cold/not passionate/apathetic). She didn't ask if I wanted a refill of my cocktail (which I would have wanted since the delhi6 was delish). Half-assed table clean up in between meals. Plus, she messes up cutlery serving (fork/knife was switched). Being nit picky bc see #3 below. 
2) mango mule was so so (too diluted)
3) not really value for the money (paid a lot for an average experience). If $$$ was lesser probably would have rated higher. 
4) takes a little bit too long in between meals
author: Reema M.

description: We just hosted a 50th birthday party for my husband at Rooh, and I can't be more pleased with service, food or outstanding professionalism it was handled with by the manager Anu Bhambri & team!! It was large gathering & we bought out the restaurant for the night. Every little detail was perfect & the party was a great success!! Thank you staff at Rooh! We will be back!!
author: Rachana R.

description:
I am here for happy hour. 

I now work at Dropbox next door (interim so pray for my skill set please, lol) 

I missed Dropbox lunch and Dropbox dinner is a few hours away... so I creeped down here and in real time I am finishing up my first drink and hh app on the cusp of my second.

I just finished the Bargemon rose and naan/chutney platter. (A bit of rose still in my glass-enough to carry me until my next arrival.) 

Man the naan is good - but naan is something basic to Indian cooking so it is not impressive when it is good... it is only scoffed when it is bad. 

The chutneys- the chutneys are awesome- it's a great introduction to what this restaurants status quo is. I had a beautiful yogurt with a touch of avocado- traditional and calming. Second chutney was a peanut and chili- Thai influenced for sure. My tastes buds where like so weird but so good! Last but not least was the tomatillo- some mexican flair! It is so awesome how I can have some credible naan switched up with one traditional and two fusion sauces. 

I have currently ordered a kingfisher beer and a scotch egg- let's pause, lol cancel that shit just arrived. 

Ok so the scotch egg is rolled in breading that is part chorizo. It is fried in a spiced oil and the combo of Indian spices and chorizo is smacking me in the face right now. It is accompanied by a house spiced ketchup as well as a house made cucumber and daikon  kimchi. I ordered his along with a kingfisher beer. 

Delicious-crispy-spicy- with that cucumber crunch. Man I could be buzzed right now but I'm really impressed. 

Bartenders are awesome. Bartenders are awesome. Carlos the bartenders first day is today and I would of never guessed, so that is awesome. I have to get on Bart now. K thanks bye. I
author: Niana D.

description: I've been wanting to try Rooh for a while and came here for lunch last week. I haven't tried August One Five but I have tried other Indian restaurants such as Rasa. Let's start with the food. It tastes fine but portions were so small that we were all disappointed with the portions. The butter chicken which I ordered, I asked the waiter if it was spicy and he said no but it was spicy, to the point where I was sweating. The waiter forgot to ask one of us if we wanted rice or naan with our meal and when they brought the food, they didn't know who ordered what. We waited for the extra naan we ordered forever. Anyway, disappointing experience overall.
author: Pierre L.

description:
Finally made it to this modern Indian food Hot Spot..
Man was I impressed from the warm welcome we received upon arrival.  Made our way to the beautiful bar where the mixologist were working hard. The manager I believe his name was Mickey was warm and looking after us like family!!!!
So we ordered the Delhi 6 cocktail with wild turkey whiskey , my better half ordered a cucumber with spices here's was good but mine was better,  she wanted to switch my drink for her drink... lol I said. We had the Potato Tikki amazing , Foie Gras was a little hesitant but wow it was amazing with hints of cinnamon and spices BRAVO . Short ribs were amazing as well and then dessert marsala vanilla ice cream with chocolate bar Amazing!!!! 
Thank you ROOH TEAM service was on point 5stars from this chef!!!!
author: Rich B.

description:
Came for an early dinner on a Tuesday and seating was easy if you sit at the bar or the high tables set for two. 
Space is beautiful, bright, and very open. The yellow couch benches are gorgeous, and the wicker chairs with an old school vibe are awesome. The color combos in this place are so great. 
Menu was organized into small plates, entrees, and large platters. Separate 7 course tasting menu was also an option but too much for a Tuesday night so we opted for a few shared small plates. All the small plates were actually much larger than I expected. 

We started with a assorted platter: chorizo scotch egg, sausage, and a shisito pepper stuffed with riccotta. The tasty morsels were served with a house ketchup, sriracha mayo, and spicy green sauce. While everything was flavorful on it's own, the sauces were a nice compliment. 
The small plates we share were the potato tikki, asparagus pepper fry, paneer chili, and tuna bhel.  I'll admit that there is so much going on with all of those dishes - they all have like a million ingredients so while i didn't really taste ONE thing in particular it did all tasty delicious. 
-The potato tikki was a mash/hash potato type with fried kale and spinach and some sauces drizzled over it. Tasty but again all over the place. 
-Asparagus pepper fry was just asparagus with a lot of yellow curry foam on it. It was fine but not for that price. Nothing interesting there. 
-Paneer chili was probably my favorite because it was paneer wrapped in some crispy fried katalfi, with a really refreshing side papaya salad, and some chili paste. Definitely nothing what I was expecting and favorite of the night. 
-The tuna bhel was definitely delicious but it just kinda tasted like a poke. 

My only issue: I wanted to order dessert but the waiter took so long to take our dessert order and by the time he came back, we had to leave. Boooo. 

I had a sip of my friend's mango mule and it was delicious. Cocktail menu was an interesting wheel chart to help you decide what to order. 
I'd be interested in coming again to try the larger plates or get more drinks.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Really enjoyed this innovative take on Indian food. Have found very few examples of good, non- standard and ambitious Indian food. This is one of them. 

We really enjoyed our dishes, in particular the vegetable/vegetarian ones. We had a chicken dish that was good as well. Drinks were excellent.

The one thing I would give his IV little bit of confusion with regard to getting seated, getting a server etc. We need up getting a team of folks who came by our table and ultimately got us well taken care of, but we weren't sure what was going on for a while at the beginning of the meal.

For those who have been to London, DC, and Vancouver (all which have similar updated Indian cuisine) here's where Rooh fits on my top 5 ranking:

1. Rasika (and Bombay Club), DC. Phenomenal food, drinks, and service, across the board, every time.
2. VJs in Vancouver (though haven't been in several years)
3. Dosa SF (different kind of food, based on South Indian, also great drinks, more established.
4a. Trishna, London (Great food, good drinks, good service) 
4b. Rooh
5. Cinnamon club, London

Will certainly keep this place on the radar next time we're back in San Francisco.
author: D M.

description:
Feels like this place is gunning for a Michelin star; check it out now so you can keep your foodie cred intact when it gets popular.

The drinks menu is inventive, laid out with a circular motif. My negroni (with mezcal and absinthe) was different- smooth but really good. My wife liked the pink city, which was pretty spicy due to chili and masala flavors.

They have full-size meals and small (shareable) plates. We did the latter; the presentations are fancy.

- Potato tikki - really fancy looking, tasted great
- Paneer chili - our favorite, looks so cool and the sauces are awesome
- Tuna behl - a lighter type of dish (with apples and mango)
- Lamb keema - very savory, comes with a tasty mousse on top
- Baked oyster - our least favorite of the 5... good, but we'd recommend a more Indian-specific dish
author: C B.

description:
Good food, bad experience.

We were visiting SF for a day, and went to Rooh on a Saturday night, on suggestion from our friends. The ambience looked great on entering, and we were assigned seats immediately.
We started with their famous cocktails, a few vegetarian and non-veg appetizers. Cocktails were good, too mild though. Vegetarian appetizers were quite average, non-vegetarian were good. 
Then the disappointing part. We ordered a few mains and breads along with it. The service went haywire after that. They started serving dishes one at a time with at least 5 minute gap between each item, and by time everything was on the table, most of the items were pretty cold. We had to ask them to change plates after the appetizers, and even after that, plates given were too small to eat properly.
Another interesting part was the bill. Initial bill was 373 dollars(gratuity included) for 8 people. After giving them credit card, they swiped it for 395. After telling them that, they came again, refunding 395, and swiping 381 this time. On asking what was going on, this was their reply, "sorry, we messed up, had some totalling mistake"
author: Vishal J.

description:
We had high hopes for Rooh but unfortunately our experience was seriously disappointing.

 Our servers made a lot of mistakes. We asked for water four times before they finally brought it out. Then we ordered Chai and after waiting for 15 minutes we were told that a large group of 6 had drank all of the tea. Then, we tried ordering cocktails and they brought the wrong drinks. A server randomly took our wine menu to another table and we had to ask for another one because we hadn't even finished ordering our drinks yet.

 The food was hit and miss, and absolutely not worth the $400 bill we paid. Again, we were repeatedly brought the wrong orders. It's almost comical how bad this experience was. It took us around 20 minutes to flag someone down to take our bill.

We thought maybe our server was new but even after repeating our order multiple times and watching him write things down, we ended up with completely random things (like a lamb dish served to the birthday girl who is vegetarian). Save your money and go elsewhere, SF is full of delicious restaurants with good service, Rooh is not one of them.
author: Shivam V.

description:
overall, the dinner was just OK.  Some of the dishes were good and some definitely missed the mark.  Service created somewhat of a broken experience.  Also, my wine pour was definitely NOT a glass (felt closer to half a glass).  Normally I don't noticed these things but the fact  I noticed makes me wonder...

We ordered a truffle dish for truffle week.  Definitely a miss.  The kulcha did not do the truffle much justice.

What was good was the aloo tikki and the pork belly.  

Food-wise, it could be good if you order the right things.

Service felt a little broken.  Sometimes we were checked up on and sometimes we were just waiting...
author: Deepti M.

description: Great Indian fusion. My first experience with that type of fusion. Try the sampler platter. Also, the mocktail drinks are fantastic. Also I recommend two appetizers and one large plate per person.
author: Alex G.

description:
This is definitely on my list of Favorite Indian Restaurants for their amazing food. 
We spent NYE and had 5 course meal dinner. Everything was amazing. I wish there was no Bollywood bash after the dinner, as their service became a bit chaotic by the end of the night, so we ended up leaving right after 12 AM.
Their prices are on a higher side, but definitely worth it. Amazing presentation, great mixture of flavors and good ambiance. Will definitely come back again for food.
author: Chitranshi J.

description:
My evening at Rooh comprised the biggest gulf between quality of food vs. service I have ever experienced at a restaurant. On the positive side, the food was stellar. The dishes had exceptional flavor and subtlety, not to mention solid portions. On par, if not better than August (1) Five purely in terms of high-quality Indian Food. I am sure I would have left feeling full, but...

My friend and I dined here on Thursday of Diwali, and despite a "full but not packed" atmosphere, the service was atrocious. Oftentimes twenty minutes in between courses without any attention from the server, and when we explained what had happened to the manager, his response was a soliloquy on a new restaurant getting the balance right between back and front of house, rather than the only two appropriate words in this case (hint: "I'm sorry"). 

Also, unsolicited advice for the staff: don't talk about hoping to get a Michelin star; you look tacky at best, and in my case, you looked downright delusional when all was said and done. If the tone if this review is harsh, it is the result of that comment and the bill being nearly $300.
author: NB K.

description: We tried the lamb chops, beef short ribs, lamb keema, tandoori roti and garlic naan. Beef short ribs were very good. Lamb chops were not good. They were boneless chunks of lamb, pretty simple and not very tasty. Lamb chops are always with bone, never had a boneless lamb chop. The naan was small and not like the authentic naan available in other restaurants
author: Khader M.

description: I just went for brunch and it was incredible.  This place has the same service and food as their fancy dinner menu for regular SF brunch prices.   I had the Mistletoe Kisses tea and a duck egg on brioche.  It might have just been a holiday weekend but the place did not have a line.  It was easily as nice as Dottie's, Brenda's, or any of the other lovely brunch places in the city.
author: Ben S.

description:
I'm so happy to see molecular gastronomy branching out into Indian Cuisine.  Starting with cocktails have infusions of south-asian spices or emulsions using chickpeas syrup instead of egg whites and through a tasting course of indian food done with modern techniques like liquid nitrogen lollipops, it was definitely a journey and the food was great.

That said, there are service issues that I would want to address if I were the owner.  Everybody was polite and the food came out at the right pace and all of that, but if you're getting a tasting menu and a wine pairing, some care should be given to talk through why that pairing was selected for that particular course, how it complements the food, where the wine comes from, etc.  For us anyway, the glass of wine was just unceremoniously delivered to the table with little fanfare or discussion.
author: Chad T.

description:
Came here to check out the restaurant for happy hour. The drinks are definitely worth while and the atmosphere is modern and fancy. 

Food wise, we ordered two small apps and two small plates. 
Chutney Sampler and naan- naan was fresh and soft and chutney was good
Rajma hummus- a let down. The chips were dry and tasteless and the hummus was bland
Aloo tikki with palak- delicious, definitely the highlight
Chicken Malai Tikka- Too creamy with little to no spice. The tikka flavor was lost and we needed to get some chutney to amp up the flavor. Felt like chicken mac and cheese with no pasta. 

The price point was also high. Four small dishes and 7 cocktails between 4 people was $150 without tip. We all left still very hungry and this was too pricey for just a snack. I would come back after the menu settles a bit or just come for drinks. All of the cocktails were delicious.
author: Vinitha R.

description:
Food alone I would give a 3.5 stars. The dishes were well executed albeit a bit small and pricey but I expected that going in. Their beer selection is good and balances some of the heat of the dishes, just wish they had better pours from their draft (not filled up). The tasting menu will not be available for a couple more months, fyi. As for the cocktail menu, it is hard to read with rotating it. Would be easier if they ad all the text aligned the same way like Aaxte does with their gin circle menu.

This is more of a lounge feel than a restaurant. The music was mostly club type music and the ambiance resembled that of a hotel bar... In Palo Alto. Some of the early reviews I read on Yelp were vague, written before this place opened or written by people with no other reviews so that should have raised some flags for me but I wanted to give this place a fair shot. 
Look at their flagged reviews, very suspicious to see so many already (16 of 32 flagged so far). That should make you question the legitimacy of other reviews especially the reviewer who said this is a Michelin caliber place.

As for the decor, a lot of effort and money was spent on the bar and I like the blue and gold accents. The servers are very knowledgeable and attentive.

Apparently you can bring a purse dog here if you keep it tucked at your feet at the bar - noted. One thing I found odd was that the owners were walking around with a cel phone in one hand and a cocktail in another observing the turnout. If this was a club or lounge that might be OK but given that this is aiming to be a restaurant, I found it a bit odd. However this is their first US venture and they do own clubs in India so maybe that is typical there.

Lastly, you probably regret not going to August 1 Five instead. Trust me on this.

Also, no need to pay full price for lunch, grab it on Gilt: https://www.gilt.com/city/san-francisco/offer/roohsffeb18
author: E E.

description:
Rooh, located in the South Beach area, labels itself as a progressive Indian restaurant. It is quite an upscale restaurant that adds a touch of fusion and fanciness to each of their dishes.

I came here with a group of coworkers on a Wednesday afternoon and opted for their Keema dish which consists of ground lamb and green peas with a potato mousse on top. It came with a buttered pao which was firm in touch but chewy in texture with a sweet buttery taste like a sweet Hawaiian roll. The Keema had a lot of various flavors, but all of them were rather mild. The sauce, mousse, and lamb were all great, but lacked a key flavor I could identify the dish with. It left me in a state of "yeah. It's pretty good." rather than giving me a wow moment. The portion also felt lacking as it felt more like a small plate than a large plate which it is categorized as.

In addition to my order, I got to try some bits and pieces of their two tasting options. They have a selection of non-vegetarian and vegetarian tasting meals, with the differences being the addition of butter chicken in the former and also different appetizers. The tasting meal seems to be the way to go as it offers a lot of goodies to form a full meal. There is quite a bit here so unless you come hungry, it may be a good idea to share some.

Overall, I find Rooh to be a nice place for a more fancy upscale Indian food experience. I do wish they added more prominence of flavors to their dishes and some spiciness to them as everything felt mild in flavor and heat. However, I would say that because of this, Rooh could be a great location to take someone who is not as familiar with Indian cuisine to in a way, ease them in to the cultural flavors with these light dishes.
author: Joshua M.

description:
If I were rating this place soley on the food, I would rate it 5. It was tasty. 

The service was laughable - I am not sure how the place remains open and "functional". We ordered 2 appetizers and 2 entrees - and ordered rice with the pushy suggestion of the waiter. However the rice didn't come out until an hour later! 40+ min AFTER OUR LAST COURSES! Also the last courses were appetizers but okay that's fine. We asked for the rice 4 TIMES!! But they have a system where you don't get one waiter - a different person comes to ur table for seating, drinks ordering, delivering drinks, taking your order for food and delivering each order! Having 5 people work with us, and asking for things leads to NONE of them taking responsibility. That is when we asked the manager for rice and he apologized and got it our just like that. There was no rice shortage. Just service that didn't care at all.
author: Foodeater F.

description:
The cocktail selection is something that was different. But the experience with food and service was below average. 

Definitely not worth the brand!
author: Bobby S.

description: Oh my god so good! This is definitely some really great Indian food. The presentation and taste of the food is traditional but at the same time very enjoyable. Also, the ambiance is pleasing with a mixture of traditional but modern Indian style. Definitely coming back to try some more :)
author: Aarti P.

description:
this was our first time in the city to dine at a really nice restaurant. We went with some friends whom did not make a reservation. You want to make one even though tis place may not be busy. We almost didn't get seated due to this. 
 We came in as a 6-top and were seated in the middle of the restaurant. The table was so squished everyone had to get close. Once side was a bench seat with pillows and the other side had chairs other tables were so close to each other that to slide in, part of you will hit and rub against the others table. 
 During Dinner, i made it to the bathroom where they had beautiful tile running from the celling to the floor. the sink was gold plated and overall it was very beautiful, and clean. Once i came back to the table. We all sat around deciding to order a gambit of items to try. We ordered pork belly, samosas, butter chicken, lamb, and a few others. I wasn't a bi fan of the pork belly, it was served with gristle running through it, made it very difficult to eat, and tasted bad. the Lamb rack was good, butter chicken good, Nann was good we ordered two types. Pannier was great. We ordered two desserts, that sounded yummy, but when we got them they tasted weird. They looked beautiful, but not my cup of tea.  
Rooh is supposed to be a Michelin  Star rated spot, but we also found that the executive chef was out of town, so we didn't receive his best. We will go back to see if the experience changes,
author: marc j.

description:
Food taste & quality is amazing. Cocktails are really good. Not a big fan of non veg food... but the lamb kheema that they serve is delicious. Carrot cake in the desert section is amazing. They serve it with kulfi ice cream. 
Its expensive but worth every penny.  I would anytime visit this place for the lamb kheema & carrot cake.
author: Praveen W.

description: We had dinner Saturday night with our brother and sister in law at ROOH. Our sister in law is Indian and had heard that this place was worth a try. By the end of the meal we all agreed that none of us would be coming back. First off, the waiter was not at all familiar with the food. This was a very uncomfortable situation as we are very familiar with Indian food and so as we asked questions the poor waiter become more and more uncomfortable. Seriously, if you are going to have waiters who are not Indian, then train them about the food and the ingredients and the variations. Secondly, the service was terrible. Our lentil dish was never delivered and while we were not charged, we would have loved to have enjoyed it. The rice had to be asked for at least three times. Thirdly are the portions. Indian food is like Italian food, it's family style, meant to be shared, and the portions are generous. These portions were like tapas, and a lot of our favorites are not on the menu. Now if you are basically afraid of Indian food, or you want to pay a fortune for little fancy bites that are "safe" for those afraid of Indian food, then this is the place for you. Forth point, the decor. The painting of the Indian woman on the wall had all of us chuckling! I mean really????? She is as white as they come! As my sister in law pointed out, no one in my family looks like that. Again, if you are wanting a hip place that allows you to say you "love" Indian food, then this is a safe bet for you. I try not to write bad reviews but when you call the only options this place gives you is to leave a message. I usually try to call the manager and express my concerns but that is not an option with this restaurant. The only redeeming factor here is that they do use some of the traditional Indian spices that we all love. If you want Indian food, don't pick ROOH.
author: Kayleen L.

description: Fabulous Indian fusion, charming service.
author: Michael J S.

description: This place was ok.  There are so many better Indian places out there however.  The soup was excellent, monk fish ok and butter chicken just ok.  Wine selection could be greatly improved.  A bit disappointed as this was our only night in the city and we dined at a mediocre restaurant.
author: Jeff S.

description: Tasting menu is really good, I didn't expect they have tasting menu, but they did really goodjob on this! Every single dish is extrmely beautiful !!
author: Faye L.

description: Just finished dinner and drinks here - it was amazing! I think more often than not, people tend to shy away from eating what's considered fine dining Indian since you can get great inexpensive takeout, but now I've seen the light! ROOH's progressive take on traditional Indian food is unique and bold and the restaurant's ambiance is no different. Highly recommend!
author: Mileen Z.

description:
Many people have asked me for references to good Indian restaurants over the years and I always say there isn't one in the Bay Area! 

However, I can very proudly say that now there's ROOH, it has the perfect ambiance with beautiful artwork, mindful music and located just steps away from the AT&T park in SF!!

However, I'm not one to go eat somewhere just for pure ambiance. ROOH has the most amazing food starting with complex cocktails, mouthwatering starters & entrees ending with desserts that one could never conjure up even with their wildest imagination!  The chef has brought together ingredients in the most harmonious way that can only be experienced at ROOH.

We plan to go again there soon and can't wait until they start their weekend brunch!!

Make sure to make your reservations. #RoohSF
author: Savira S.

description: Went with a friend for dinner. I got the Banaras sour cocktail, which is a drink that really features the chartreuse, and is presented beautifully. Can also recommend the butter chicken. Pretty good.
author: Ricky D.

description:
Wow, that was an incredible meal. Went with two colleagues/friends, and we shared 4 starter plates (Potato Tikki, Kashmiri Lamb Ribs, Chicken 65, Keema Hyderabadi), and then shared a  couple main dishes as our entree (Butter Chicken Pave, and Tandoori Season Mushrooms). Everything was fantastic. I even brought the smallest little portion of the chicken and mushrooms home that we couldn't finish because I knew it'd be great the next day, and couldn't watch them toss it out. Just finished it for a small lunch snack. Still incredible. Go with friends so you can enjoy the variety of flavors on each plate. I'm going back soon. 

p.s. good service too. Knowledge of the plates and great presentation.
author: Chris L.

description:
Rooh is a true representation of modern India combined with some authentic Indian flavors. From their cocktails (Madras Kafi) or starters (Jhalmuri / Bhelpuri) to their desserts (Banana Tarte Tatin)... everything was a treat to the eye and music to your palate. Service was great... Oh they even sent us a complimentary dessert while we waited for our order. This is definitely my newest favorite #roohsf 

(PS: I may have got the names completely wrong)
author: Bennet M.

description: Enjoyed the food though expensive. My wife really enjoyed it. amabience is great
author: Dr. Manisha Punwani, M D.

description:
Cocktails: 4/5. They are great, good variety and great blends
Potato tikki: 5/5, crispy, tasty and refreshing
Lamb Shank: 5/5 gravy was delicious and the lamb was cooked to perfection
Green  Jackfruit dumplings: Gravy was mediocre but the dumplings were great and made up for the gravy
Mango something Tart: 5/5, most delicious dessert. Bits of mango, cream and crispy 
Breads: 3/5, can definitely be better. 
Service: 5+/5. Very attentive to all guests, great recommendations. Extremely impressed with the staff and their knowledge about the menu was outstanding.

Overall great experience and its nice to know there is an Indian place in they city with good ambiance, food, drinks and service.
author: Milana R.

description:
Very disappointed with service and quality of food. The bartender was taking 15 minutes to make a drink. In a Friday night .. are you kidding me. 
The food was lacking flavor and way too expensive. 
The sea bass was good . There lamb shank was soft but nothing special. The Keema was the only dish that had some flavor. Chicken 65 -- meh; butter chicken - terrible;
Assorted parads for $10 --
You really don't want repeat customers.huh

Without a good chef and good service no matter how good the ambiance , is not going to last too long.
author: Sand T.

description:
We went with a group of friends, we were looking to try something different in the city and were really excited when we landed up getting a reservation after many tries. Unfortunately, it was a total let down. The small plates were fusion Indian starters which tasted decent but the quantity was minimal. The large plates were really bland and lacked flavour. We ordered quite a few items from the menu and there's not one thing I can comment positively on. 
We also found the service a bit pretentious and annoying as they describe each food item when they come to serve it. Honestly just a waste of time and effort for the servers
 
The only saving grace is the ambience, cocktails and the music this restaurant plays. Overall, save yourself some $$$ and avoid eating out here. You can just come to hang at the bar and have some quirky cocktails!
author: Misha M.

description:
Seems like a great place. 

I'm not sure if it's the wrong jersey or the wrong skin color but according to the bartender after a Giants game I'm not welcome to a drink, but the two white girls that walk up later are.

The General Manager seemed like a great guy but the 1st interaction left a terrible taste in my mouth.
author: Peter A.

description: Taking all factors into account (Food quality, taste, presentation, ambiance and service) the weighted average undoubtedly deserves no less than 5 stars.   Best Indian Food in the City: Check.
author: John S.

description: Excellent Indian food place in San Francisco. Food is extremely good and served on time. We had paneer pinwheel, chicken malai tikka, lentil kulcha for dinner. All of these items were really well prepared. Definitely recommended for date nights and family night outs.
author: Piyush K.

description: The food and drinks here weren't bad.  Great brunch place to go to if you like Indian food. When I was there they were busy but still maintained to deliver good service. I recommend making a reservation.
author: J C.

description:
Meh!! It's all I have to say about this place. I live in the SOMA area and was rooting for this place to be good and exceptional. I loved the idea of a fancy Indian food/ fusion food.
All this is, is generic food with great presentation, half the size and twice the price. 
I have given then 3 stars for their cocktails .. which are impressive and appetizers are decent too. 
Can't make it my go to restaurant. 
Amber you still have my stomach
author: Justyna R.

description:
I have to give it a mixed review. The food was absolutely amazing. The service was absolutely terrible. 
When we first got in, we had expressed interest in wanting to do the tasting menu with the beverage pairing. When you do a tasting menu with a pairing, it is the server's JOB to explain the wine which we get with each food item and how it enhances the taste. We should know the bottle and year if it's asked, which our server did not know. On top of all of this, we realized at the end, that our wine pairing was running slower than the food. So at the end of the meal, we had one entree and 3 glasses of wine in front of us. How is that a pairing? Why would we pay $40 extra for a wine pairing if you can't even PAIR it correctly? 

If this wasn't bad enough, the managers who walked around were very judgmental. As my husband and I are relatively younger, it felt as if the managers were purposely ignoring us as they assumed we didn't understand food or wine. They went around to every table in our area except ours. When I asked one of the managers in which order I should eat the entree presented to me [there were sauces, meats, sides etc], I got a very rude response. I didn't feel welcomed or appreciated as a customer. 

It's not all bad though. They really have done an excellent job with the food,and perhaps this lack of service would not have been noticeable if we hadn't done the tasting menu, it's hard to say. The chicken tikka masala was created very well. The twist on the pani puri, while very different, managed to keep the original flavors; it was delightful. They have really worked hard to create a very one of a kind menu.
author: Aastha V.

description: A very good take on local Indian classics. Loved the cauliflower 65 (surprisingly served on an uttapam) , veg pulao made out of three types of rice was probably the best pulao I had in US. Chai cocktail was unique and amazing.
author: Samrat V.

description:
I've been fortunate enough to try ROOH multiple times and each time has been the most amazing experience. I love how the menu changes frequently because I'm always excited to try something new. From their amazing cocktail menu to their fabulous wine selections to choose from, you will definitely be happy with your adult beverage. They also have fancy Indian tea that comes in the most beautiful tea set.
Usually we'll order family style to taste and share everything. For lunch, I usually get a vegetarian or non vegetarian platter because it has a variety of items to share. Love the asparagus pepper fry, cauliflower65, chicken65, fish amritsari, butter chicken, pork belly, lamb ribs, vegetable dumplings, maple leaf duck, lamp chop and beef short ribs! Yes, just a few!! =) I've also tried all of their dessert which I highly recommend! I'm not a huge dessert person but I always get a dessert when I come to ROOH. I definitely want to check out their brunch that they started doing on the weekends! 
Also, there's plenty of parking in the area which is so rare in SF!
author: Deb C.

description: This was quite literally an explosion of flavors in my mouth. The dishes were so creative and flavorful. We ordered the chutney sampler, cauliflower dish and dahi Puri in small plates and the grain veggie pulao, baby aubergine for entrees. Heads up, expect the small plates to be well small :) but no less delicious. The aubergines were cooked so perfectly and served in a delicious peanut gravy, absolutely recommend. We polished off with the carrot mawa cake which was yummy. I liked the kulfi on the side more than the cake itself, but that's just me!
author: Gayathri M.

description:
Overall my experience at ROOH was good! I'll just give a brief overview of my experience.

When I first arrived I felt like the host was not very friendly - he was this way throughout my entire time at the restaurant. It's a shame, really, because my waitress Marija was so friendly! I had the chef's tasting menu and was there for about 2 hours. The food was quite good - very interesting as well. I think the price was fair. In regards to the ambience...it was quite attractive. My only complaint is that the interior was a tad cramped and I was squished by one of the windows for the entire meal, but it was tolerable. On the other hand, the bathrooms (well, the men's, specifically), really seem out of character in conjunction with the dining space. They were definitely an afterthought and should probably be thoroughly redone given the upscale vibe that ROOH is trying to embody. At the end, the check came right away -- so I can't complain about that! 

I would probably come back here with some friends, perhaps - I went alone this time. The bar looked well-stocked so this could be a good place to visit for the happy hour, although I do believe theirs ends quite early - around 6, but I could be mistaken.

I definitely left with a fairly good impression, but I did not love ROOH. I think next time I will try some of the more traditional options. Their butter chicken is quite delicious - it was offered on the tasting menu - so I anticipate that they nailed the classics across the board considering butter chicken is a good litmus test for Indian restaurants in general. We shall see!
author: Tevin M.

description: My boyfriend and I went here on a Friday night. After trying Babuji, August 15, Rasa, And Aslam Rasoi, I have to say this is probably my new favorite Indian restaurant in the city. It was their one year anniversary so they gave us complimentary champagne and the staff was super friendly! We opted for the tasting menu which came with 6 courses. They also have drink accompaniments for a higher price. My meal consisted of pani and dahi puri, a stuffed kulcha, ribs, monk fish, and beef short rib curry. There are yummy vegetarian options for all the courses. The pricing is on the higher side, but well worth it. The decorations are beautiful and the ambiance is great! Definitely would recommend this restaurant for a date night in the city.
author: Priyanka S.

description:
My husband and I had our luncheon for our city hall elopement. We were struggling to find a restaurant to accommodate our party for a specific time. We were fortunate to find Rooh. Despite not being open during that time, they were able to accommodate us. 

Their staff were also very helpful and the food was delicious. The icing on the cake. Would recommend!
author: Erica Q.

description:
This was the best dining experience I've ever had, no exaggeration. The staff was absolutely lovely and so knowledgeable about the items we received. Each dish was so delicate and beautifully plated and the flavors were phenomenal. Everything we tried had their own unique flavor and was satisfying. The DAHI PURI was probably my favorite! I could've had the whole dish to myself and then some! The cauliflower and asparagus were so yummy. The BUTTER CHICKEN was mouth watering. The sauce that came with it has to be left on the table so you can RIP and DIP! Oh and the CHICKEN MALAI KOFTA was to die. I scraped the entire bowl for the cheese sauce they cooked it in. And I cannot forget the TUNA CHAAT! This dish was so light and refreshing and something I could eat all the time. 
 Oh! And don't forget dessert. The cashew cake was sooo delicious. 
You guys will not be disappointed here. Go try and be with people who will be down to try anything. Mind you , this restaurant  is a new modern take on Indian food, so if you come in here expecting to have something you've tried before you'll be wrong. Everything is new, vibrant and incomparable to most Indian cuisine so take a chance and go.
author: Vanessa H.

description: Imaginative cocktails. Great food. Seasonings and sauces were well seasoned and presentation was nice. As good Indian as I've had.
author: Tad M.

description: The cocktails were great, but this food is for Americans looking for a taste of Indian food. It's not particularly authentic. Additionally, it took us nearly 2 hours for us to get our food which I thought was unacceptable and the cocktail service was also slow.
author: Jeff M.

description:
Incredible take on Indian food. I love this place. Went here for my birthday and it was the best present I could have asked for. 

They have a super in-depth cocktail menu, really knowledgeable servers and actual mastery happening back there in the kitchen. I had no idea anyone could spin Indian food to this level without losing all the best flavors, spices and essences of that hearty, flavorful home-cooked feel.
author: Liz R.

description: ROOH doesn't disappoint like most high end Indian Fusion restaurants do. The dishes here actually balance Indian inspiration with Western precision and flavor influence. Case in point: they had a tuna tartare with crispy papar which was delicious. I could eat it for lunch every day! They also had a lot of vegetarian options. I would recommend going here either on a very empty stomach or with a group of people, because although the portions are conservatively sized, you're going to want to try a lot of things on the menu. I was in a group of 4 which gave us a chance to try several appetizers and an entree, along with a dessert. The service was polite, although I got the impression that they don't treat their bussing staff that well. My server rushed the busser who was filling our water glasses and the exchange seemed tense.
author: Meryam B.

description:
Food was great and 'Progressive Indian' as promised. We ordered Sev puri, Chutney sampler, Jackfruit dumpling, naan and a side of rice (I know, a lot for 2 people, but we are gluttony :p) . Jackfruit dumpling was my favorite. It was unique, very well cooked and flavorful.

For dessert, we got Carrot cake, which was a twist on the Indian Carrot halwa/pudding. It came with pista kulfi. IMO it did not come close to beating the carrot halwa. This Carrot cake was good on its own. Wouldn't call it exceptional, but good.

Service was great! Only initially they gave a table right next to a huge group of people who were very noisy. (we were looking for a quiet birthday dinner). However, after we requested, they moved us to another table without any questions. The tables could be placed a little bit more sparsely to allow more room for a nicer lunch/dinner experience considering it is a fancy restaurant.
author: Ranjana K.

description:
Came here on a Thursday evening for drinks and a few small plates. Overall, loved the drink menu concept it was innovative. However, one of the drinks was totally copied from Babuji, lol. Except, they missed the mark on it. It's the drink that was made with beets. 

Fav small plates - chicken 65 by far. Delicious and beautiful presentation. The tuna bhel was fantastic as well. However, we ordered dessert and it took them 20 minutes to bring it out. Lol. I need to come back to try their larger plates!
author: Tina J.

description: 'Rooh khush kardiya'! (translation: made my soul happy). SPLENDID food! The intricate layers of flavors teased our tastebuds. Certainly going back for more!
author: M S.

description: Went for lunch. Upscale and nicely decked out restaurant / bar. Really enjoyed the cauliflower, potato doughnut and butter chicken. Will be back for a cocktail next time.
author: Casey P.

description:
One of the best Indian contemporary restaurant in San Francisco. We ordered almost everything from the menu and each and every item had a unique and tasteful appeal to it.

Butter chicken, Keema & Aloo Tikki were show stoppers.

I would highly recommend this restaurant to anyone!
author: Sanchit G.

description:
My wife and I had come here On a date night! We absolutely lovely the food! Dahi Poori and Alook Tikki with Kale tempura left us craving for more!
Paneer pinwheel was delicious ! And the carrot halwa cake was divine ! The cocktails were enjoyable too! Highly recommend!
author: Ram V.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed my experience at Rooh this past weekend.  

Very creative drinks.  Love the presentation of the Firdaus.

Small plates were all full of flavor, quite literally a party in your mouth.  Large plates were good but the small plates really stole the show. Once again, great creativity and presentation.

Didn't realize that the operators also operate Olive in Mumbai which is also very good.

Finally a great Indian option in the Bay Area.
author: B P.

description: Ghee old fashioned!! Or was it a Manhattan? I can't remember but it was really good (interesting twist). Tried their prefix menu during SF restaurant week. There was a large party ahead of us so took about 1.5 hours to get our main course but overall great ambience and good food.
author: Rachana M.

description:
Ordered the following:
Small Plates 
  Chilli Paneer - great presentation, and flavor 
  Goat cheese naan - fresh and very tasty

Entree 
  Garlic Naan - well, it tasted like garlic naan 
  Vegetable Dumplings - very nice colors and flavor
  Paneer wheel - great presentation but kinda bland 

Overall, a great new Indian place. SF needs more out-of-the-box Indian places. Prompt service and great drinks. At 70-80$ per person, I expect a) everything to be organic. I'm not sure if that's the case b) every dish to be impeccable . The paneer entree missed a beat. 

4 stars but will try again.
author: Madhu M.

description: I work nearby & see this restaurant buzzing during lunch & happy hour. I had my reservations before I went in but that was quickly put to rest. The staff here is wonderful! They are knowledgeable about every item on the menu. I had the butter chicken & lamb chops with garlic naan. The butter chicken is well flavored & has a nice kick to it. My girlfriend & I enjoyed it so much that we ordered a second order of naan so we could wipe up all the the gravy! I was afraid the lamb would be gamy however, it to was well seasoned & tender. It is a bit on the pricey side however, it's worth it.
author: Maneesha C.

description: Our favorite fusion Indian restaurant. Everything that we tried had an amazing twist to it and the drinks were lovely!! Upscale place and yet so kid friendly. We've been back many times.
author: Puneet B.

description:
This restaurant is just the kind of high-end Indian restaurant with a flare that we've been waiting for. 

We went with a bunch of friends and so ordered half the menu listings and ate family style. Everything we tried was delicious, tender , flavorful and again with a flare. 

There cocktail wheel is a brilliant idea and makes picking a drink a lot of fun. 

It's a place you would want to go back to for every special occasion. 

My favorite - lamb chops.
author: Samreen J.

description:
Went here to celebrate hubby's birthday. Really loved this place. To start off, the tuna bhel was out of this world good (why hasn't anyone else tried this combination before?!) and the aloo tikki (accompanied by yogurt and potato mousse? and fried kale - sounds weird but it all paired perfectly together) was sublime. For main course, we got paneer rolls, dal makhani and sea bass -all very well prepared. They even brought complimentary dessert (carrot cake - just ok although the accompanying kulfi was delicious) since we were celebrating a birthday. 

Well done Rooh, we'll be back.
author: Priyanka G.

description: Came to SF on whim so didn't really make dinner Rez for a Friday night.  We are Indian haha and looked up Rooh and figured why not give it a try and OMG was so good!  We were seated at the bar which offers the full menu.  Bartenders are wonderful, very service oriented.  We really only had 4 of the appetizers and then some drinks and it was so good.  So unique but not weird - great blend of new ingredients in our typical Indian dishes, made to perfection.  I will be back for sure- thanks Rooh!
author: K P.

description: We live near Chicago and heard about this restaurant from a friend. The menu looked intriguing for an Indian restaurant, so we thought we'd give it a try.  The food was so delicious that I had to write a review, which I rarely do.  First off - the chutney starter had three very different flavors which I never before had tried, but we all scraped every bit of the chutneys from the bottom of the cups because they were that tasty. We ordered five of the small plates, all of which were good, but we especially enjoyed the asparagus fry and dahi Puri. Finally, the tandoori mushroom large plate was simply incredible. I had never had a dish like this before at an Indian restaurant, but it was so flavorful and unique, we loved it.  Beyond all of this, the service was great, and the drink menu was very cool (we got the Pink City which was great too!).  Highly recommend this place!
author: S M.

description: Really like the food, great presentation, elegant ambience with the right amount of informality. Took clients out for dinner here on a 9 course meal and it was fabulous. Would be great for date night as well.
author: Sukruth P.

description:
If you love Indian food, outstanding service and are willing to try something new then ROOH is a must.  My son and daughter in law told is it was one of the best meals they have ever had and they both have experience in the restaurant industry so we decided to go there with them while visiting them in the Bay Area.  Hands down one of the best meals from food, to service to ambiance . I can't even tell you what was best as it was all delicious ! I would suggest trying the 7 course tasting menu and since you can choose from two things in each course you can both order it and try a bit of everything!  A definite must if you live in the Bay Area or are
Planning a visit !
author: Tammi L.

description: Lovely food and service . But just be aware this is an America. ( Californian) version of India food , mostly small plates .
author: Anish K.

description:
It's pretty inside.  That's about it really.  If I'm going to splurge on Indian food I'll take august 15 (that place was legit).  But $100 for 2 apps and 2 mains (and NO drinks) would be fine if the tastes unloaded and the tummy was full.   Neither happened.  To be fair the apps were fine and unique...Although pricey at $15 each.   Now the trend I've noticed so much in sf: downhill from here.   

The girl's duck was teeny and not unique even though it had a sauce on it. ..no indian flare at all.  The roasted root veges on the side were lame (I still remember the frigging carrots at petit crene...yes,  carrots).  

Then the butter chicken....3 nuggets in pretty much a tikka masala you'd get at any indian place 60% cheaper.  Yeah. .. $26.

Don't forget your naan and tiny rice for $5 each. 

No desert. No need.   We had a slice of pie waiting back at my place from Gregory's in Oakland.   I doubt this place could compete w that. 

So Rooh, Als place,  Aster, Belotta and all the downhill reataurants: stop catering to the young rich by making it pretty + $$$ so they are impressed and believe that's the recipe for "good."  Be like petit crene (quality + quantity), or belloti and cala (impressive although not good value, but appreciated).  Having generic taste and being expensive and leaving me hungry?   Piss off.
author: A A.

description:
We love Indian food so it was great to find a new high end Indian restaurant in SF. The food was good but I was very disappointed by the service. We arrived early as we usually do to have a drink at the bar. They also class themselves as a cocktail bar. When we checked in at the front desk we were not welcomed in the normal way. The response from the front desk staff was 'oh you're early'. This was the weirdest hello I've ever received at a restaurant. My wife suggested that we go to the bar and the front desk agreed that was the only option. 

At the bar we were given menus but it was an age before we were served. I was getting pretty frustrated as the bar was quiet and there were almost more staff than customers. However, I realized that only one guy could make the cocktails out of the 4/5 people behind the bar. Everyone else was just cleaning pots and looking busy. 

We ordered appetizers at the bar which were very good. However, we were called to our table before we finished. I asked the member of staff if we can bring them to the table and he told me sure we can carry them ourselves. Again, this stuck me as strange. However, I carefully carried my cocktail and appetizer plates across the restaurant and slid past other diners as the member of staff strode quickly away. 

This restaurant has potential if they sort out the service and make it more customer friendly.
author: Stephen M.

description: Great innovative Indian fusion food, very nice and colorful ambience, and friendly staff. Probably the only thing that could have been improved was the masala chai, which didn't have much masala but was good nonetheless. :)
author: Akshay Y.

description: This was some of the best food I've had in awhile and made for a great birthday meal. It's not typical Indian food - it has all of the flavors, spices, and techniques, but they use atypical ingredients you seldom see in India: jackfruit, kale, and certain meats.  They also splice the cuisine with Mediterranean and Pan-asian flavorings as well. The staff was perfectly accommodating and the drinks were pieces of art on their own; can't wait to come back.
author: R T.

description: This restaurant has the perfect blend of indian taste and contemporary fusion food everything that we ordered tasted perfect. Little far from the hassle of downtown and very calm atmosphere. One of my new favorites
author: Suman D.

description: What a beautiful restaurant; serene setting in a very urban environment. Food was really good, an interesting take on Indian cuisine. I don't usually associate Indian food with being"gourmet" - Rooh demonstrated this model works well. I'd come back just to have the rice again, it's amazing
author: Dan W.

description: I came here for lunch and it was pretty damn good. Really enjoyed the ambience during lunchtime; there are not too many people so I can enjoy a nice lunch with some good friends. The menu is very simple so I made the dining experience very stress-free. You have the choice of two main entrées today we had the choices of chicken or paneer. I myself chose the chicken and it was delectable. The chicken comes In a yellow curry sauce that goes really well with both the naan and the rice. Your meal also comes with avocado raita, papad and chutney, And to start with as an appetizer, You get some crispy spinach and kale which I highly recommend trying some time. Overall, I think this was my favorite Indian restaurant that I've tried in San Francisco if you have a heavy wallet and some change to spare come try out ROOH. you'll walk out with a full stomach and a lighter wallet but you'll be happy you came.
author: Patrick L.

description: Contemporary Indian cuisine with an exquisite dining experience. Loved the paneer wheel. One of the best Indian restaurants of the SF Bay area. A lot of thought has gone into every aspect of this trendy restaurant and it shows up in the way every item on the menu is prepared. You'll be one satisfied diner.
author: Harsh P.

description:
Food: perfect blend of modern, California cuisine with Indian flavors that touch the heart.
Drinks: I'm not sure how many visits would be needed to try them all, but I've gone twice so far, and that was not enough. It's hard to pick which is the best drink! 
Dessert: If you're not already in food heaven by the time you've finished your food, then dessert will definitely push you to the other side. I've tried the Tutti Frutti Cassata, and the Saffron Malai Tart so far, and can't wait to try more. 
And lastly, the most important element, excellent service!
I've had a wonderful experience both times I've gone there, and can't thank their team enough for creating such a pleasant ambiance!
author: T A.

description:
1 star: something really bad must have happened. Would never come back. Guarantee I'll yelp review it to vent out my anger.
2 stars: wasn't horrible, but don't like the place enough to ever come back.
3 stars: good. Would come back if it was convenient or I had no other choice. Wouldn't make an effort to recommend to people.
4 stars: really good. Would make an effort to come back. Would recommend.
5 stars: outstanding. Will recommend to everyone to try. Will most likely make an effort to come back.
----------
The place is a SOLID 4 STARS. I want to give it 3 because now that I'm writing a review, I realized that we never got our first course! Also, it took 45 mins (yes, we timed it) for our third course to come out. I'm still giving it 4 stars because 1) our waitress continued to apologize and update us several times for the wait, 2) a gentleman who I assume is the manager came out and not only apologized, but also comped us one tasting menu, and 3) shit happens. I'm not a super anal yelp reviewer who thinks the workers to should bend over backwards for me.

Came here for SFRW opening day with 2 other friends. This place has been on my list of places to try for a long time and I thought PERFECT! Time to try as this is their first time participating in restaurant week.
Since there were 3 of us, we were able to try everything that was offered on the menu minus the lamb, which none of us are fond of.

MENU: Five Courses - $65 pp  

Appetizer  
- Canapes
5/5: tasted like a very light, bite size, Indian seasoned taco. Who doesn't love tacos?

First Course
- Green Peas & Goat Cheese Kulcha
0/5: sadly we never got this ):

Second Course
- POTATO TIKKI
5/5: this was my favorite out of the menu. Best way to describe it is as a crispy kale salad with potatoes. Super bomb!
- DUCK SHIKAMPURI
4/5: basically a duck meat patty

Third Course
- ASPARAGUS PEPPER FRY
3/5: good, but nothing special.
- ACHARI MONK FISH
4/5: fish was light and cooked perfectly. Loved the sauce that it was in.

Main Course
- PANEER PINWHEEL
4/5: it's basically paneer tiki marsala
- TRADITIONAL BUTTER CHICKEN
4/5: aka chicken tiki marsala. Chicken was surprisingly moist!
- BEEF SHORT RIBS CURRY
- 3/5: the actual short rib was a little dry. There was also this fried ball of short rib meat (don't know how else to describe it) that was super moist that saved the dish

Accompaniments
- Avocado & Garlic Raita
1/5: tasted like plain greek yogurt straight from the tub
- Saffron Rice
3/5: it was basic saffron rice
- Garlic Naan
4/5: flavorful and fluffy

Desserts
- CARROT HALWA CAKE
4/5: cake was moist & not too sweet. The pistachio kulfi (basically ice cream) was bomb!
- MASALA CHAI & CHOCOLATE PAVE
2/5: obviously this is just our preference, but the cake was just too dense and sweet for any of us to enjoy
author: Annie N.

description: Delicious vegetarian friendly brunch options in such a beautiful setting. Every detail was taken care of and the dishes were inspired - I especially enjoyed the masala omelet and the chili and Parmesan kulcha!
author: Claire S.

description:
Reserved a table with friends. Upscale, modern yet cozy decor. You can hear each other without hearing the customers next to you. There is a subtle in the restaurant and an appropriate vibe.
Servers provide accurate information on menu items and recommendations as well as attending to the tables in appropriate intervals. Unique and fun cocktail options were sampled but the star is definitely the food. Small plates with enough portions for three people to get a bite then large plates full of flavor also shareable. Their take on Indian Cuisine is definitely a treat to be had.
author: Vernon S.

description:
We came here for a special lunch date and this place totally lived up to the "hype". I had the cocktail with Assam tea, and it was refreshing and very unique. 

We ordered from their brunch menu and everything we tasted had a unique interpretation of an authentic Indian dish. The food was very flavorful, looks beautiful and was very satisfying. We ordered a bunch of (2-3 per person) small plates and shared, so we could try more stuff. Service was attentive and comfortable (not crowding). 

Highly recommend trying this place out if you are looking for a fine dining, Indian restaurant.
author: S S.

description:
My wife and I ate at Rooh last Friday and absolutely loved it.

We lived in London for several years and developed pretty high standards for Indian food.  Rooh did not disappoint.   Super cool interior.  Very sophisticated food.  We had the potato tikki, lamb ribs, tuna bhel (sp?), & fried chicken.  Everything hit the mark.  Will come back the next time we are in SF.  Well done Rooh.
author: Rob C.

description:
Brought my girlfriend here for her birthday this last Saturday and I really enjoyed the food and ambiance. We had the Chutney Sampler for an appetizer, Jhalmuri Bar, Charred Sweet Potato as Small Plates, Traditional Butter Chicken as Large Plate, and Chocolate Ganache Cake for dessert. I also had a tasty Banaras Sour cocktail. The presentation was beautiful and the flavors delicious. 

The only reason I'm not giving 5 Stars is because the service was extremely slow and it wasn't that busy. I figured they were short staffed but excuses aside, we did wait too long in between courses. Our server was strangely consistent asking after a few bites how our food was but would not come back for ages after we finished so we can order more drinks or even dessert. We were eager to try more but lost interest as the night went on because of the slow service. Would come back again though with hopes of service improvement.
author: Jay T.

description:
Went back again and was happy to enjoy the cocktails. The bar was completely empty but none of the bartenders even looked at me and my friend at the bar for 5-7 minutes. They were busy chatting amongst themselves and fidgeting with glasses and bottles. It was like we didn't exist. Then when they did "see" us they took 7-10 minutes to make the cocktails and literally there were 10-12 people in the restaurant and 3-4 at the bar. How come they don't care? We were livid that they seemed to not care at all that we were waiting while they were chit chatting. Management should really look into this. 

The food itself was good. We ate the lamb app, the fish for the entree and chicken for entree. All were very good and seems refined. This would have been a 4 or 5 star review if they hadn't screwed up the experience. Chef has done a good job with food and it's a huge improvement from my last 2 visits.
