I'd like to patronize this place as we work in the building but word in our office is that the service is too snooty when the owners are not around.
author: Rohan D.

description: Fantastic! Loved everything about this place. Food, service, ambience. I'm a fan! We've already made reservations for Saturday night.
author: Alex N.

description:
Incredible delicious food! My husband and I love eating at Indian restaurants around the city, and I would rate Rooh as one of the best places to eat Indian food in the bay.

The food tastes amazing and the presentation is beautiful too. The chefs provide a god combination of traditional and fusion options.
author: Shivani M.

description: All I could say WOW!  Went here for the first time today for lunch and cant wait to come back for dinner. The flovers were on point! Been to couple of new Indian restaurant but there was something missing. Rooh doesn't only have there plating to wow you with but there us also flavors to give you the yummy teast in your mouth! This place had me planing on my next visit before I even left the restaurant. Yummy yummy in my tummy!
author: Sunil M.

description:
Come here for the cocktails and stay here for the food. Modern creative bar menu. The fat washed old fashioned was fantastic, with a subtle creamy mouth feel. 

Oh and get the Naan. Some of the best I've had!
author: Sylvia L.

description:
This restaurant is absolutely incredible. It's on the level of any of SF's finest restaurants, but the food and drinks are so much more interesting and flavorful. The owners have several other restaurants-- but all in India. This is their first establishment in the US.

First, the drinks. Curated by Mickey, they are absolutely incredible. The wine list pairs with the meal perfectly and the cocktails are incredibly unique. Just look at the way the cocktail menu is designed!

The food... oh, the food. Let's just say I can't wait to go back. The butter chicken was incredible and the desserts... just perfect.

Can't wait to be back!
author: Ian C.

description: This is my new favorite Californian infused Indian place. We came here for Sunday brunch and we ordered 6 different dishes and all of them were incredible! The service was great, the waiters were all so nice. We're coming here more often!
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description:
Elevated Indian food, inspired by all regions in India.  We went here to dine with a group of friends, the environment was elegant and optimal for dinner conversation and catching up.  Not one dish was disappointing.  The flavors and texture of the food were top notch.  Although they had an impressive selection of cocktails, we opted for a nice champagne and it paired beautifully.  
The naan is excellent.  Favorites from the meal are small plates Tuna Bhel, Asparagus pepper fry and Keenan Hyderabadi.
author: kathryn c.

description:
Spicy happy hour.
Elevated Indian.
You should ROOH the day.
author: Nish N.

description: The food was good but not out of this world, unlike their prices for the serving.  This was definitely one of those restaurants where we left $300 poorer but so hungry we actually went to another restaurant for dinner again!  The drinks menu was really inventive and interesting but they should tell people if they're planning to charge virgin drinks at the same price.  There are a number of fancy Indian restaurants opening up right now and while I'm hopeful for the friendly owners,  I'm not sure this will survive in a highly competitive market.  Everything was simply too expensive for what we received.
author: Win L.

description:
I went there for the restaurant week and was really impressed. Everything was GREAT! I had already the potato tikki and I knew is delicious but was impressed with everything else: fish monk delicious and special, the filled pastry - forgot the name - was a highlight, etc.
Service great as well -good pacing of the meals and really attentive staff! Good experience - highly recommend!
author: VIORICA C.

description:
Just book it. You won't be disappointed. Went at the weekend as a group of three and it was sublime. Food was amazing, service outstanding - remarkable for a resto that's only open 3 weeks... One gripe - the dessert menu descriptions do not do the desserts justice. We were about to pass, were persuaded, and they were unbelievable. 

Menu highlights: The "liquid foie gras" pate, the fried chicken, and honestly everything else, but make sure to order these two.
author: Barry O.

description:
This restaurant is deserving of five stars. The food is authentic and classy with a modern twist. I myself have been to tons of Indian restaurants, and it's safe to say this is one of the best. The staff is professional and knowledgeable about all the dishes and the presentation is spectacular. 

We tried the Non Vegetarian Platter and loved it! The butter chicken and dal in particular were great. The Tutti Frutti Cassata and the Chocolate Cake were beautifully decorated and the perfect way to end our meal! Our bartender, Arthur, made amazing drinks and was great to talk to. 5/5 definitely recommend!
author: Vahini P.

description:
The food was very tasty. The service was unpolished and awkward.

My date and I met up at this new upscale Indian restaurant to try out their tasting menu. The space is beautifully decorated and very elegant. We were presented the regular dinner menu, the cocktail menu, the wine list, and the tasting menu. The most interesting one was the cocktail menu, which had a circular design. I had to spin it around in order to find what I wanted - the delicious mango mule.

The 7 course tasting menu was $80, which seemed in line with other places in pricey San Francisco.

Several of the courses had vegetarian and meat options; since we decided to share everything, we basically tried every item on the tasting menu except for the vegetarian entree: paneer pinwheels.

All of the courses were delicious. My favorite was the fish; It was perfection in my mouth.

I found the "entree" courses of butter chicken and short rib vindaloo to be very true to traditional Indian recipes.

For dessert, I liked the Chocolate Ganache cake (with masala chai ice cream, hazelnut chikki, and buckwheat crisp) and he preferred the Carrot Halwa Cake (with cardamom and pistachio kulfi, milk skin crisp). I was quite happy with the food from both a flavor and presentation standpoint.

We had three main people providing service - the person who took our order, the person who presented the dishes, and the person who refilled the water. The first two were not good at their jobs. The guy who brought out the dishes stumbled over the descriptions of each course. Does the tasting menu change every day? If not, he should be able to memorize clearly what is on it. Shortly after guy #2 would bring out the dishes, guy #1 would come by to check on how we were doing. He didn't do a reality check when he proceeded with his rehearsed script. He would ask how something tasted when it was clear we had not yet even touched the plate. Could he not tell that the entire presentation was in tact? We told both guy #1 and guy #2 that we were sharing all of the courses yet sharing plates were removed with every course but not always replaced. At times, utensils would be missing. The guy who refilled our water was on top of it! Kudos to him.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Nice people, but pretentious, over priced food. The atmosphere is lovely, and the servers are friendly and helpful, but the food is unimpressive. The only dish we enjoyed was the potato tikki with flash fried kale. It had a nice combination of flavors. The cauliflower had a spicy red sauce on it that added little to the overall dish, and there was very little other seasoning that came through. Similarly, the butter chicken and lamb chops were bland and uninteresting.
It was $200 for three of us which was a princely sum for mediocre food.
author: Gwen S.

description:
Service: 5 stars (I was apprehensive because of some of the prior comments, but our server and the other waitstaff were great - informative, prompt, friendly)

Drinks: 4.5 stars
I had the Hyderabad Tonic, which was delicious and pungent.  I liked it the moment I smelled it.  My husband had the mango mule, which was good but not as much to my liking.

Food: 
Small plates: 5 stars; We had the liquid foie gras pate, the potato tikki and the tuna bhel - they were all amazing. They each had some alteration or special seasoning which gave them an extra oomph.  Also, they were not as small as I had thought they would be. Perfect for sharing between 2-3 people.

Large plate: 3 stars; We had the butter chicken (mainly because I wanted to eat naan and wanted the sauce).  While the dish wasn't bad at all, it was just decent. However, it was also very SMALL - 4 small pieces of chicken.  I'd hardly call that a "large" plate.

Dessert: carrot cake - 3 stars.  I was the most disappointed in the carrot cake.  It wasn't terrible by any means, but the flavor was underwhelming and the portion was tiny. 

Overall, we had a great experience and will be back - but maybe doing more of an assortment of the small plates.  There were plenty that were recommended on Yelp that we didn't try.
author: B. Y.

description: Rooh! Loved the ambience and the food was yummy! We ordered the guvava soda mocktail, vegetarian platter and the charred broccoli and sweet potato salad! Simply Awesome! We ordered the chocolate cake with masala chai icecream for dessert, it was top class! The icing on the cake was that the dessert was on the house since we were celebrating a birthday! :) Five stars!
author: Divya C.

description:
New kid on the block down in SoMa, but a very welcome addition to the neighborhood. Ambiance was great, service was fine dining quality without any of the snobbery. The food was excellent - I will say that I was a little put off initially by the menu, expecting to get Tikka Foams and Naan Gels and aerosol of chutney or whatever molecular prep du jour might be on offer. What I got was well prepared, immaculately presented and hearty Indian cuisine, artfully crafted with great depth of flavor and a surprising amount of complexity and finesse. 

The portions were not as large as one usually expects from an Indian joint, especially for the price, but if you are ok with a smaller quantity of outstanding quality this is your kind of place. 

The Tikka Pave was outstanding. The duck korma was very unique, and the various chutneys were delicious. An Indian spiced chorizo stuffed scotch egg?? Omg. Stop talking and start eating.
author: Jon S.

description:
Every ABC Bachelor season my boyfriend and I compete. Whoever calls the winner or gets the furthest gets a free dinner paid by the other. So when Nick got down on 1 knee for my pick Vanessa, I scurried to find a cool new restaurant to try out on my boyfriend's dime. ;) 

This restaurant is super cool, love the ambiance and the vibe. 

Our experience started off a little shaky, I made reservations on a Friday night and the restaurant was about half empty. The hostess led us to a small table that was VERY tightly spaced next to people on either sides of us. It was uncomfortable, especially when it's a big restaurant and there at least 10 empty 2 tops. We asked for another table and they said it was reserved. (We reserved as well!) so we were a little annoyed that they were saving better tables for other reservations. We ended up switching to a hi-top table. right by the door. Still a little uncomfortable with not a lot of table room, but we decided to brush it off and continue. 

We had a very nice and attentive waiter. He went through the drink and food menu with us and recommended his favorites. 

The drink I ordered came in a Tea Cup and Kettle which was BEAUTIFUL and super tasty. 

We ordered a couple small plates and one large plate to share. Everything was INCREDIBLE. Really, it was some of the best Indian Food I've had. I was pleasantly surprised. My favorite was the POTATO TIKKI.

The prices are steep. We shared 1 entrée and only had 1 cocktail each and it was still over $100. 

That being said, I would definitely come back here again on a nice occasion. Great addition to the neighborhood. I do hope they work out the kinks at the hostess table but I'm sure that will come with time.
author: Paisley P.

description:
A whole lot of money for a whole lot of meh.  But while the food was mediocre, at best, the service was fantastic.  Our waiter could not have been more attentive.  Great guy.  As for the food, we tried the sampler platter (scotch egg, pickles, beet croquette, pepper stuffed with a soft cheese, battered and fried) so bland and the fry was not the best...over cooked.
Lamb ribs appetizer - like it had sat out too long so the sauce was slightly congealed. And while the sauce was ok(overly sweet) the meat had no real flavor. 
Chicken tikka appetizer - came in a sauce that again was slightly congealed and way too salty (and I like salt!)
Tuna biehl - was actually the best thing we had.  Great combination of textures and flavors.
Butter chicken - ok. 
Sea bass - they put this lightly Curried sauce over it that again was too sweet and lacked any real depth of flavor. 
Saffron rice - good
Naan - good for 2 minutes and then turned as hard as a cracker. 
Nothing horrible. As I said meh. 
But I was expecting quality with their beautiful website and the prices they charge!  But sadly just not worth it. Save your money.
author: Monica K.

description:
The restaurant had excellent reviews so we decided to try this place for the first time. We went with reservation for 7 people on Saturday 21st October which was Diwali Weekend. To our surprise they were serving a limited brunch menu. 

They had 5 options in the bigger Entrees out of which 2 were sold out at 12:45 when the restaurant opened at 11:30 AM - Cornish Hen and Vegetable Biryani. So we had to order two of the same kind. 
They had 3 choices of Mocktails out of which one couldn't be made as they were out of Coconut Water.
The food was mostly creamy with loads of butter and cream. The flavors did get suppressed because of that.
We had:
Dahi Puri - Must try
Chicken Kulcha - Must try
Paneer Chilli - Okay
Cauliflower 65 - Must try
Chicken 65 - Okay
Fish and Shrimp Starter - Normal fried fish - Can be skipped - Way better at August1Five
Chicken Biryani - Very good. Must Try
Paneer Makhani - Way better at August1Five
Black Dal - Very bland due to excessive cream.

Service: Bad.
Since I am pregnant I chose the Pink City Mocktail. They added Rum/Other Liquor which was completely unacceptable. They weren't even apologetic for that.
Garlic Naan came 10-15 mins before the main entrees arrived. They changed it for us when we asked but again were completely unapologetic for the same.

Guess the day we chose wasn't the right one. August1Five was a way better experience in my opinion.
author: Reema I.

description: This place is like experiencing Indian food at a whole new level. Every entree was delicious and with a California twist. Met the chef Sujal Sarkar, so humble for him to comeout and chat with us. Nice to meet you Vikram, see you around the neighborhood. Best Indian food in the bay and a true tastebuds feast.. can't wait to go back!
author: Parag M.

description: Coming from a mouth of an Indian, the best Delhi style chicken tikka masala I have had in the area. It simmered for perfection and butter infusion on a fresh white meat. The lamb shank was outstanding, along with the crazy cocktails. Pujan is a wonderful chef, this is my to go place for future nice evenings.
author: Dibyendu R.

description:
+: the food is delicious and the space and atmosphere are great 
-: the service is really really slow (30min to bring a glass of wine and we order 45min after we got there), hopefully they'll get better; and it is quite expensive for what you get (potions are ridiculously small)
However since the food is really good I would still recommend to give it a try
author: Louise U.

description: 58 mins and still no appetizers. Yes it was a big Diwali weekend but place needs to plan ahead. Very sad and disappointing experience.
author: Amber B.

description: This is a pretty good place for Indian dining. Went there on our anniversary. Service was great and so the food. It was a unique test of Indian food compared to what all other Indian restaurants are serving in the bay area. Drinks are good as well. Surely going there again.
author: ALAP M.

description: Butter chicken is pressed, service was friendly.  Bill was a lot more than most places, but most places also don't serve crispy noodles stuffed with paneer and the potato tikki I had the chance to enjoy (maybe Vik's?). Anywho, will go back!
author: Choladeva C.

description: 3 of us dined here at 6 pm on Tuesday...the place was hopping even at that early hour.  Lively crowd in the bar, we were seated towards the back behind the hostess stand where it wasn't too loud but you could still feel the energy.  The menu says "Progressive Indian" but I would describe it as Gourmet Indian.  Shared a chutney platter, the Sea Bass, Short Ribs, and Butter Chicken.  I can't tell you which one was the best because they were all delicious.  Perfectly done and the sauces were to die for.  Portions were reasonable, presentation was a work of art, and service was friendly and responsive. Cute pinwheel cocktail menu that guided you toward your taste preference--I had the Mustard Old Fashion that didn't taste any different (to me) than a regular one.  Good--but nothing special.  House Pinot was very good and paired well with all of the dishes.  I will be back to Rooh and often!
author: Dawn W.

description: Good cocktails, sparse menu which they try to make look fancy but it's ok, I would have still rated them 5 but for something which is not that exceptional it's a bit overpriced.
author: Priyank M.

description: Came highly recommended by desis in the know. Great ambiance, drinks, menu choices. Delicious food. Only disappointments were the daal makhani and the butter chicken. Chutney sampler, aloo tikki, and paneer chili were all great. An amazing addition to the SF scene.
author: Andrew K.

description: Awesome restaurant. Taking Indian traditional food / dishes and giving them new gen. While doing so still retaining the flavor and taste. Great staff , good decor and great chef !
author: J R.

description: We were disappointed with the overall experience. I took few friends to celebrate the 50th birthday because saw good reviews. The menu description of cocktails and dishes were fancy but nothing tasted out of the ordinary. The website pictures were very presentable but our dishes did not come with any such garnishments.The location is not convenient and finding a parking is a challenge. It was busy and the attending staff seemed not to pay attention. Even the hostess was running around while the phone was constantly ringing.  It seemed more like a noisy, unorganized, unclean fast food restaurant.
author: Marvel J.

description:
We had a reservation for 730, I called in and spoke to a woman around 7pm let her know we are running late, she says no problem just come-in by 8pm. When we get there I'm told our reservation was cancelled because we are 25 mins late. After waiting another 20mins we get a table. The whole experience after that was just downhill. Mediocre service to be kind - I had to ask for our waiter at least 3 times during the meal.  Who then couldn't understand English well or any of the Hindi named items on the menu 
Just go to Dosa or August 1 Five instead...
author: Joe J.

description: Knew this place by name and decided on the first night in SF to try it out. It was so good that we couldn't eat all the meals in one evening, so decided to come in again on the second night. The pork belly was amazing and their take on tuna bhel was very refreshing. Their mango mule was by far the best version of a Moscow mule I've ever had!
author: Daven P.

description: The best Indian food I've had probably ever. On the smaller side portion wise, but more than made up for it with how tasty it was. Can't wait to come back!
author: Brian W.

description: 10 for service 10 for presentation but the food was just not worth it. Flavors we're not amazing and even after covering the table with "large plates (they were small) and small plates (same size) there just wasn't enough food and way too expensive. Wouldn't go back but experience was nice
author: Mariam D.

description: My boyfriend and I came here because we saw the amazing happy hour reviews and I must admit I could not agree more! We came and enjoyed our experience there. The food was amazing and the drinks were so tasty. The bartenders were so personable and friendly. I can't wait to stop by again!
author: Bianca G.

description: Appetizers are to crave for! Full marks on food, ambience and service. Won't help comparing Rooh with any other Indian resto, because there ain't any resto like Rooh. :-D
author: Sàgar C.

description:
Hands down the best Indian food I've had in the SF Bay Area! Delicious! Soo soo good. Also the most expensive Indian food I've probably had in the Bay Area. 

They have a great choice of cocktails (try the City of Joy or Filter Kafi!) For the small plates, definitely try the charred sweet potato- that malai broccoli with it is amazing! For the large plates, we had the paneer pinwheel and the vegetable dumplings. Both turned out to be excellent. We forgot to order any bread with the large plates initially, and later ordered the mint and chili laccha paratha. The paratha was tiny but buttery and crispy. Couldn't taste any mint or chili though. For dessert, we had the moong dal baklava. Again, turned out to be an excellent choice.

Overall, it was a fantastic meal. Can't wait to come back and try their tasting menu!
author: Priyal M.

description:
Overrated , the cocktail was pathetic . Ordered the chicken lasun dish it was such a tiny serving and so tasteless .
I would rather have indian food at some mom and pop place than this one
Such a rip off
author: Rahul A.

description:
Went to ROOH last night with my daughter. This review is about some of the food we ate there.

Mumbai Sherbeth - was good - but could have been great if only the bartender had gone slower on the ice cubes he used. At $10 a pop it was about $9 dollars worth of ice cubes - you get the drift, right?
Chicken65 presentation was amazing - but lacked the zing. Question - why cut out the middle of the uthappam? It is not visible in the presentation - so not sure what I am missing here.
Kashmiri Lamb ribs - this was truely great. The lamb ribs were perfectly cooked and melted in your mouth.
Lamb chops - Again most amazing - however I would expect at least one more piece for the price we are paying. $12 per piece is way too much - and the chops were not sizable to boot.
Channa curry - this was really bad; Please, please do not order this. Tasted like it was out of a pre-packaged packet. Smelt bad and tasted badder. If they don't do a better job at this - better to remove from the menu.
Saffron rice - was good, but did not enjoy because of the bad Channa curry.
Banana Torte - Amazing. This was really great - it takes about 15 minutes to make - so order along with the main course to get it early. But is well worth the wait.
Overall it was a good experience - but for the issues I have highlighted..
author: Vinoda N.

description: This is a favorite restaurant for special occasions. The food is ingredient-driven, beautifully presented, and satisfyingly delicious, thanks to the modern take of the chefs and not-too-small portions. The space is knockout gorgeous as well. Super creative food and design makes it one of the most inspiring restaurants to eat at in SF.
author: Anita L.

description: First visit to Rooh!  I came here for my birthday and had a few other friends to enjoy it with - in true fashion, more showed up than I had estimated/reserved for but the hostess and staff were very accommodating and helped us enjoy a lovely meal regardless.  The wait staff were very attentive and also quite gregarious.  They enjoyed helping our group pick out our meal items and were nice enough to accommodate some of the party that had dietary restrictions.  I really enjoyed the experience, the service, and the food - as did the rest of the group!  I'll definitely be coming back to enjoy another meal at Rooh :)  Well done!
author: Priti M.

description:
We wanted to like it, but honestly it was just not all that impressive. 

First, no tasting menu without advance ordering. Okay. Too bad nobody let's you know when you book. And even though 80% of the items are on the regular menu they were apparently sold out. 

Second, they offered to let us take our drinks to our table and then came back and said we had to close our bill to move. Minor issue but they should be able to handle this. 

Third, waiters would consistently overlap duties with food questions and descriptions. Yes we would like tap for the third time.  

Finally, the food. Some decent stuff but most was mediocre to poor.  The curries were all too sweet.  The sauces and chutneys appeared multiple times across dishes lending a sameness. World class high end Indian exists - Junoon and Tamarind in NYC, a couple places in New Delhi and London. But this isn't even close. I'd rather go to Ajanta or Viks in the East Bay or Dosa by Jtown.
author: T N.

description:
Mutton biryani, keema hyderbadi, and chicken tikka kulcha: 
Filter Kafi: 
Good brunch spot with outdoor seating. Service was fairly quick. Will have to come back here for their tasting menu for dinner!
author: Shatarupa N.

description:
One of the best fusion cuisines in Bay Area 
--Delicious Indian fusion food
--Creative cocktails
--Friendly staff 
--Chic ambience
author: Alex P.

description: I was invited to dine at Rooh recently and had my taste buds absolutely delighted. They have taken Indian Cuisine to the NEXT LEVEL. Each dish was prepared to stimulate your eyes and the flavors worked in harmony making them sing. The Cocktails are amazing! I could tell everyone that was picked to work there was the best at what they do. I'm definitely coming back...
author: Meikee M.

description: Yum! I absolutely loved the food here.  Drinks are pretty fun and tasty too. The only problem is that it is a bit steep so we won't be coming back regularly.
author: Susan M.

description: I'm actually a little surprised by some of these negative reviews here....I thought this place was fantastic! I was very pleasantly surprised. It's a gorgeous space and is perfect for a Giants pre game meal. It s creative and fresh and we loved what we had. We started with the Organic tomato kut...sort of a burrata with awesome flavor and spices. We moved on to the butter chicken (the best I ever had!) and the beef short ribs curry. (The most tender beef I think I ever had...yummy!) we also got a bread sampler and the naan here is perfect! This place is definitely high on my list and I'm sure we'll be back again and again.
author: Jim M.

description:
We went to Rooh for dinner today. What an amazing experience! Chef Sujan Sarkar is a wizard, who keeps the 'Indianness' in the food while giving it the cosmopolitan (if I may use such a mundane term) twist to every concoction.
It respects the palate while teasing the senses.
Will be raving about Rooh and going back very soon - it's only a 65 miles drive for us ;)
author: R R.

description: When they say progressive Indian cuisine, the truly are. Very unique and atypical flavorful dishes with superb presentation. Servers are well informed about dishes to be able to recommend. Portions may be small for the price, though.
author: Abhinav T.

description:
The cuisine is OK (seems like a copy of few types of restaurants), nothing original and creative. If you are a cocktail fan and do not care what is in it, you might like it. Poor selection of wines.

The worst part about this restaurant is its service. The service sucks and to my bad luck I got the same waitress both times I went there, she said I am supposed to order all my food at once (appetizers, main, etc.), I asked her why? and in a rude tone her answer is "because the chef prefers it that way and so that you don't have to wait". I said I am willing to wait what is your problem lady as I don't even know what mains I want until I am done with my appetizer.

Yesterday a bunch of my friends went and I believe they had a terrible service too, the waitress kept telling them what they ordering is not enough in a rude tone without them even asking and she made them order more than what they could even eat. There was so much food wasted.

These kind of places are ok when they start as people are excited about a new Indian restaurant that looks good in SF downtime but they don't last as they don't care about the overall experience.
author: P V.

description: Came here with no expectations and left with ROOH becoming one of my new favorite Indian restaurants.
author: Vinay A.

description:
Traditional Indian cuisine with modern tadka. I loved the presentation . Portion is small and can be shared in 2. 

Dishes you shd def try

Paneer Pinwheel
Chilli Paneeer
Malai chicken bake

Cons
Paneer Pinwheel and butter chicken  shares same gravy. I expect them to be different given it is  a $$$ restaurant

Overall , I liked this place and would come again .
author: Lisa M.

description:
I'm going to update my review. 3.5 stars. I'm giving the owner / manager (who humbly reached out to explain) the benefit of the doubt here. This is solely because I feel like I need to give them another shot and next time I'm there I will ask for the manager. I will order all of the above food and drinks again. 

Rooh, you have to wow me the next time I'm there. You've got a lot of potential. I love frequenting Indian restaurants because SF just doesn't have good Indian options. You're the newest kid on the block and we want to love you.
author: Sean K.

description: Great food and ambience - currently the best Indian in the Bay Area. Would recommend for the uninitiated to Indian food and the Indian food junkies alike.
author: Rohit V.

description: Amazing food and presentation. My new favorite Indian place in SF!
author: Rachel Z.

description: Pricy but so good! Went with a group of 10, and we were worried about getting everyone fed and happy with the portions. We ordered well and all dishes were crowd pleasers. Expensive but we were happy.
author: Sarah M.

description: Don't bother going to this restaurant for the tasting menu. First course pani puri was fine but nothing special. Tasted like every other pani puri I've had before. The second course kulcha was so bland and had so little filling that it might as well have been naan. The third aloo Tika was ok... the plate was mostly crispy  kale with chaat flavors on top. Fourth course asparagus pepper fry was the worst of all the courses. No flavor at all. Fifth course paneer pinwheel was just a giant wheel of paneer in standard tika Masala sauce... nothing special and no vegetables in the curry. Last course was chocolate and chai dessert which was was the most average dessert I've ever had at a fancy restaurant. It tasted like normal brownies from a box mix with slight chai flavor. And in addition to all the boring dishes, the wait staff brought out all the dishes so slowly and then right after we paid the bill the hostess asked us to leave because another person was waiting for the table. I've never been asked to leave a table at a restaurant, but it felt even more ridiculous when we made a reservation for a tasting menu and the restaurant staff were responsible for it taking so long to finish the meal.
author: Amber F.

description: Everything we ordered was delicious from the lamb to the mushrooms. Very flavorful dishes. The ambiance is nice too. Great for a date night.
author: Sandra S.

description: Where to start !! Over all experience was top notch !! Time I had spent was fully enjoyable!! Drink was made  with perfection !! Appetizer special assorted papadum concept was unique!!  Keema was little under seasoning for me coz was born and raised in Asia I don't found kick on dish !! Looks of dish remind me shepherd pie !! Attentions towards Guest make me to visit in coming future!!! Finally  malia thika reminds me back in India !! Elegant restaurant of India!! Lamb shank made with perfect !! Delicious Gravy !!
author: raja g.

description: We had a really wonderful meal at Rooh this past weekend. Food was superb, drinks yummy, service excellent. Our friends had been there several times so knew the couple running the restaurant so we got to meet them..but we received no special treatment, it is always nice to meet the people responsible for a good restaurant. Decor and ambience also make for a nice atmosphere in which to dine. I dropped them one star because of the cost...this restaurant is very expensive indeed. Plan on spending at least $100 per person for a full meal. Will I go back--yes, but at this price point probably not as often as I'd like. Glad to see more upscale Indian restaurants now, the cuisine is one of the most interesting and diverse I've tasted.
author: richard c.

description: delicious garlic naan.  we had the sea bass with the madras curry glaze and it just melted in my mouth - best dish!
author: Stephanie L.

description: My friend and I made reservations and spent several hours enjoying the cocktails and shared food. However the service lacked and after spending over $200 we were told to vacate our table even though we still had half full drinks. We were not offered a seat at the bar. If you are going to charge that kind of money for Indian food and drinks then follow through with your service. Once your bill is paid be ready to go.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
So I'll confirm the food here was good.  We didn't have a bad dish last Saturday night.

But the service here was atrocious -- almost to the point of spoiling the meal.  The server was clearly green and didn't know the menu that well.  He even tried to tell my Indian-American  vegetarian friend the clearly vegetarian portions of the menu.  He rarely came to check on us and when he did he offered a promotion for brunch the following morning!  There was a half hour in between courses and it took us asking three people and 25 minutes for the bill.  Food was cleared we asked to take home and waiters would try to take food we were still working on.  Just mass chaos!  If you can look past this for the food, maybe worth a shot!
author: Jo W.

description: Where has progressive Indian food been all my life? My tastebuds are still happy just thinking about Rooh. We stopped in for happy hour after a game- so traffic could die down; and got great nibbles with lots of flavors.  The staff were so attentive and knowledgeable about the food. Bartender got my cocktail just perfect. And now I want to go back for the dinner tasting menu!
author: Pam W.

description: Went there for a very late light dinner. The place is very trendy and the meals were well presented and tasted great. Plus the service was excellent.
author: M A.

description: Came in on a Thursday for a cocktail and happy hour appetizers. Here is my initial assessment; Décor: Chic, aesthetically pleasing, and very comfortable.  Atmosphere: Intimate without being intrusive. Great vibes and a full bar at 6 pm! Food: Only had a few appetizers but all were stellar.. great spice and a true feel of elevated authenticity..and finally Cocktails: The cocktails were so on point! Jeffrey the beverage manager has created this (mind blowing) flavor wheel for cocktails and it had my taste buds in a frenzy! I love that you can customize your cocktail experience according the flavor wheel and will know exactly what to expect when your first sip hits your palate. I will definitely be back!
author: Michelle G.

description: We went for dinner. The menu is written really well and is impressive. However after that everything went downhill. The service was poor. We ordered a cocktail and it took 30 minutes. After asking our server repeatedly, we were told that cocktail has been removed from the menu(well then why is it still on the menu). After appetizers, we had to request to clean the table. The food was mediocre at best. For the price you pay, there are so m any better restaurants in the city.
author: Suresh K.

description: Food was innovative ! However, server claimed food was NOT spicy for kids! And it was! They didn't have lassi for dinner service to help soothe the spices for the kids! God knows why not as most most Indian restaurants offer it! They provided Raita and charged for it! They should have comped it! Service was decent! They provide a complimentary appetizer. Music was too loud!
author: Bill K.

description:
The food is meh. Save your money.

I mean it is hygienic and healthy, but the tastes are quite ordinary. Lighting is at best okay, so the food doesn't look that great either. Portions are outrageously small for the amount of money they're charging. 

Overall, I wouldn't go there again. I'd also spend a few mins of my life convincing my friends to not go there!
author: Nandan S.

description: The best food ! We went on Tuesday night. We were seated fast. Staff was lovely. But the food's the star ! So satisfying. We had aloo tikki, paneer chili and mushroom dish, so amazing twist to Indian food, loved it. Cocktails are also fun to try, we had mango mule and Mumbai sherbet, enjoyed both.  Slightly on expensive side but perfect for special nights.
author: Vaidehi D.

description: So delicious! Lots of vegetarian options that were both gorgeous and tasty. Really friendly staff, too.
author: Clara B.

description: Updating my review because Rooh got in touch with us to refund the corkage, as well as gave us a gift card. We were really impressed with this level of service. We're looking forward to going back, and this time I will take pictures of how the food looks when it comes out, which is impressive. Thanks, Rooh!
author: Sara M.

description: We tried tasting menu and it was amazing. Every course was original and sophisticated. It's even not like usual Indian food, it's really progressive. Moreover, all the people working there are really friendly and and nice.
author: Helen M.

description: Amazing food. Small plates baked chicken is to to die for. The best chicken I've ever had. Do it!
author: Tatyana V.

description:
Alright, here's the thing...I was trying to decide between three and four stars and decide they get four stars based entirely on the food.  It'd be five stars, though, if the rest of the night went according to plan...

To start, I made a reservation at Rooh, because both my boyfriend and I are so intrigued by the concept of an Indian tasting menu along with not-just-wine beverage pairings.  

We get to the restaurant at 7:28 for a 7:30 reservation. We're told our table isn't ready, but that it won't be more than ten minutes.  That's fine--I get it.  We sit at one of the two-top tables by the bar and are greeted by a server (who we wound up having all night and who was fabulous).  We order drinks, which take about fifteen minutes.  This wound up being okay...because our table wasn't ready until 7:55.  So we eat. And we're hungry. And we're excited.

We sit down and look at the menus and notice there is no tasting menu.  We ask about it. "Oh, we're not doing that tonight, because we have too many reservations."  Okay...so you only do the tasting menu on nights when you're slow? Why offer a tasting menu if you can't offer it on nights when you're at capacity?  I get that it'd be tough for a kitchen to handle a full menu and a tasting menu, but then maybe only offer it on certain nights...or, ya know, don't fill the restaurant if you can't handle both offerings for everyone there?  We were incredibly disappointed, because we came across the Bay just to try their tasting menu.  I'll be honest, I came close to walking out, because at the price point, I really wanted to see what the chef came up with for the tasting menu rather than blindly guessing at food I wasn't familiar with.

However, we stayed, because again, we came all this way.  We ultimately ordered a variety of things (recommended, in part, by our super friendly waiter) and they were all (mostly) amazing.  He even tried to pick out the most popular items from the tasting menu and explained what they were in more detail. 

Small plates: the lamb ribs and the tomato/burrata kut.  Both were 5 stars.  The tomatoes were just slightly warmed through and the flavor combination was stellar.  It's also served with this bread and when we asked what it was, we were told "well, I like to think of it as an Indian foccacia" and that description is spot on.  Think foccacia with cumin.  So absolutely awesome.  And it paired great with the kut.  The lamb ribs were fall off the bone tender and when we asked if they were sous-vide the response was "oh, we sous vide pretty much all of our protein." Smart.  

Large plates: the butter chicken, the sea bass, and their mushroom dish.  The butter chicken was fantastic (I'm new to Indian food, so my boyfriend said the flavor was definitely better than what he had experienced at other places, but not by much.)  The sea bass was cooked to perfection (again, sous vide), but the sauce is definitely peanut-y.  I hate peanuts and was really bummed about this, because I don't think the menu mentioned peanuts as a flavor profile, but maybe I missed it.  The mushroom dish was also super awesome, but definitely on the rich side.  I only had a couple bites and then focused on the naan and butter chicken. 

Sides: saffron rice & naan sampler with avocado raita.  All good. All standard.

Wine: again, we were planning on beverage pairings.  Luckily the wine director dude (who also had the awesome responses above) made a suggestion based on what we were having and it was spot on.  He also said that they're changing the tasting menu + beverage pairings in the next month or so, so I'm excited to see what he has up his sleeve.

All in all, I'll definitely be back.  However, I'll make sure to call the day of to make sure they're still doing the tasting menu.  As a pro-tip, if you know you're not going to be offering a big part of your whole shtick, how about you call the people with reservations and update them so that if they don't want to travel an hour to your restaurant, they have the option to cancel?
author: Shannon B.

description:
Over priced. Interesting menu and flavors but flavors could be better - eg NiharI having such little gravy is very weird and the flavors themselves were gamey. The meat, while well cooked, had not absorbed the flavors of the curry (we are Indian, and very familiar with the flavors they're trying to replicate / achieve) Great cocktails. Nice decor. 

Bad service - the servers are not educated about food allergies and have no attention to detail. I am gluten intolerant and the server was not very knowledgeable about the menu wrt this. Worse is he went to ask the chef some questions and came back with responses that made no sense (e.g. "This item is not made gluten free because chef says potatoes have gluten in them". Really?) Ultimately we ordered what they recommended and even then had a reaction when I came home. 

My friend who is nut allergic received a dish laced with peanut, despite having requested it be put on the side. He found out only after taking a bite. This was followed by a perfunctory apology and a replacement of the dish. It would have been common courtesy to knock the dish of the bill / dessert on the house / some indication of an attempt to improve the dining experience - but no such effort was made.

All in all, for the prices, I'd expect : better food, more options accommodating food allergies or at least the willingness to customize (indian cuisine is one of the most food allergy friendly cuisines) and better service. Sad to have wasted $200 for a special dinner here.
author: Yelper 2.

description: Great food, cocktails and service. We finished a delicious meal then decided to stay for another drink. The staff was kind enough to stay with us, and serve us with great hospitality. They even apologized for people who wandered in wearing pyjamas and wanted to be served  love this place!
author: YinYin S.

description: This has become my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Everything that we have tried is excellent- from the naan and chutney to the paneer pinwheel. The tuna bel and the dahi puri are melt in your mouth. Service is excellent.
author: Lida T.

description:
Rooh has taken the Indian food scene to the major leagues, in SF! It has been less than a month since they have opened, and we've already been there 3 times. 

The decor and ambience is very ethnic and classy, their attention to detail shows.

Service - their service has been top notch, the owners - Vikram and Anu are quite involved every evening, to make sure things are going ok. Their staff know the ingredients and menu quite well and are good at making thoughtful recommendations. 

Cocktails - I love the wheel, where they have classified their cocktails based on flavor - sweet, pungent, sour,  bitter & salty. We have tried almost 6 of their cocktails, all of them are really good.

The Food - I am vegetarian - I still found a lot of options to chose from. I love their Chilli Pakoda, the Potato Tikki was delicious and took me back to Delhi, Paneer chilli, in the small plates is also very nice. In the entree section, I liked their Paneer Pinwheel. Don't bother with the portobello tandoor it stuck out like a sore thumb on an Indian menu, even the flavors were bland and not very Indian. Highly recommend their dal makhni & laccha paratha.

My husband LOVES the Prawn Sausage & butter chicken (very authentic)!

In desert - highly recommend trying their carrot cake. It was delicious!

Strongly recommend visiting Rooh to get a taste of India :) Please keep up the good work and high quality, Team Rooh!
author: A S.

description:
Went to lunch with a group of coworkers yesterday. We were excited to try out a new place, especially an attractive Indian alternative to our old standbys. Very nice place. We were greeted and seated quickly. Attentive waiter. So far so good.

We ordered cocktails to celebrate a fake birthday -- someone somewhere was having one -- and after a brief Q&A with our waiter we ordered. As is typical for our lunch event, we just went straight to the entrees. The food came quickly but as it was placed down we all made eye contact with each other at the small size of the portions. They were tastefully arranged art pieces but this was, after all, an Indian meal and we expected to get fed and full. The food was tasty enough and we all enjoyed it but to a man we all felt like we'd had appetizers and joked about going somewhere else to eat on the way back to work. 

Although the portions are small, the prices are not. At $20 per entree this was definitely on the high end of what we manage for lunch, but coupled with the very small portions we weren't happy. 

Next Indian we'll stick to the local faves which are both tasty and (too) filling - North India, Chaat Cafe, etc.

Oh, the cocktails were tasty, mid priced, but at least of the normal size!
author: David F.

description: Amazing food and wonderful service.  Do yourself a favor and get the short rib. Soooooo good. Will be back!
author: Uri L.

description: Good authentic food with some unique touches.  Would definitely return. I could fill up on the small plates like the Jhalmuri Bar and chicken65. Only complaints were that our dishes were served luke warm and the service was a little over eager. The restaurant was not full but we could barely get through a conversation without the waiter asking if we wanted more- it felt a little rushed.
author: Jill S.

description:
I was really looking forward to eating here. We were 4 of us. We had Placed our order which included cocktails, appetizers and entrees. Some of the Appetizers came in around 15 mins, they were served with the side dishes that we ordered for the entrees. We had to remind the waiter about our cocktails and a missing appetizer, which he seemed to have forgotten about. Anyways, the remaining appetizer and cocktails came in another 15 mins. 

After another 30mins had passed we asked about our entrees and the waiter assured us it'd take 1-2mins more. In another 15 mins we asked for an update. Waiter said another 2-4 mins and said he'd call the manager to assure us. Another 15mins later we demanded to talk to the manager. At this point we had been there 1.5 hours and no sign of any of our entrees (although our entire order was made all at once since we got at the table). Meanwhile, the manager shows up and tells us it's "restaurant week" and orders are taking longer than usual. Tells us it'l take another "2-3 mins". Another 15 mins go by, we ask the manager to cancel our orders. He tells us he's sorry and we can have our food packaged but in at least  "5 more mins", but can't assure us if it'l still be within 5mins. We ask for the check instead. The check showed they charged us 20% gratuity and had incorrectly listed us as a 6 person table. We demanded they take off the gratuity. We spent 2 hours there only to have left without dinner. We could have left an hour earlier had they told us it's a busy day and our orders were to take this long. Instead they kept misleading us with "2-3 more mins". The mismanagement of time expectations was what riled us up. This place is too expensive to get away with such bad service. There was barely any remorse expressed by senior management. This "take it or leave it" attitude is unacceptable. I'm never going here again. 

P.S. A different waitress who came to clean our table while we were leaving apologized profusely and hoped this wasn't the last time we came here. She was the only person who seemed to care the entire evening. Can't say the same about the manager or anyone running this place.
author: Gautam K.

description: Good ambience and decor! Food was nothing extraordinary. I would not go again - paying all that money fir the kind of food i can surely get elsewhere!
author: Experienced C.

description: My favorite high end Indian restaurant in the bay area so far. Cocktails are topnotch, and the taste of the food was a good balance of fine dining and intense flavors.
author: Mihir P.

description: Really great new restaurant with a super modern twist on Indian cuisine. ROOH had good service, amazing drinks, and an appetizer dished called Chicken65 that is incredible - we ate it for the first time then immediately ordered a second. All of their cocktails are well thought out and perfectly balanced and are very different than what you'd get anywhere else in San Francisco.
author: Ashley M.

description:
sf has been flooded with higher-end indian-inspired cuisine recently. yikes. came to Rooh for weekly girls night because it was in the neighborhood and we are all about that hot n new lately.  the space is really beautiful - the three of us were seated in an alcove-like space partitioned by gold curtains. the blue booth gave a very rich color contrast. it's hard not to fall in love right away.

got handed 3 dinner menus, a cocktail menu, and the wine list. dove into the cocktail menu - it reminds me what trick dog or aatxe did - drinks sorted by flavor profile, then by ingredients and shape of vessel that the beverage came in. good concept, except that you had to turn the menu in 360 degrees to read it all. eh. i ordered the old fashioned - huge ice cube and very little drink, okay flavors. i graduated to the mango mule - much better, thanks to the copper mug.

we asked for recommendations, but only a couple items resonated with me. being an indian-inspired spot, i thought the menu was a little scattered. not a lot of curries, no real typical indian dishes, unlike august 1 five, where you can find your cheap favorites done upscale.  we got: scotch eggs to share, burrata, chicken tikka (not masala), grilled portabello, sea bass, pork belly, and the assorted naan basket. my gf's REALLY liked the naan (expected to be stellar) and the burrata (not sure if this was indian at all?!?).  one of the girls LOVES pork belly, and didnt even finish her piece. at $30+ per plate, that's not really acceptable. it was dry, and lacking in flavor. my favorite was probably the chicken, although a little chewy at times, majority of the pieces were tender and sauce was warm and inviting. everything else was just fine. scotch egg was good - but you know...it's an egg dish...  

service was all right. you can tell that she was a relative newbie and was somewhat nervous and awkward. we got offered new plates between each course, which i appreciate, but really no need.  dinner and drinks was $80 pp after tax and tip, which is pretty extravagant for a monday night. i much prefer august 1 five over rooh.
author: Christina L.

description: Went for Saturday brunch.  Delightful setting.  Excellent service.  Wonderful food.  They call it "Modern Indian".  Definitely different from most Indian restaurants.  Delicious and different options:  just let your server describe them and then choose what appeals.
author: Stephen G.

description: Got a chance to try Rooh this evening during happy hour.  One of the finest Indian restaurants to try in SF.  Their old fashioned, Delhi 6 and Beetroot Kanji was awesome.   In terms of food, we tried a number of vegetarian dishes, the chili paneer and jhalmuri bar were phenomenal.  We left with wanting to try more and made friends with the great team there promising to return.  If you are in SF worth the trip to ROOH.
author: Kamal S.

description:
Visited this place on a Sunday afternoon and I was impressed. The food, ambience and service is exceptionally very good. The manager was very friendly and courteous and our server was very knowledgeable about the menu and prompt. I liked the decor and comfortable seating.
Definitely going there again!!
author: steve d.

description: This is one of the best Indian Restaurants, I've been too. All of the dishes we enjoyed were new and fresh takes on our beloved traditional dishes. We came to celebrate a birthday and were delightfully surprised with their friendly service. The only complaint is the quantity of the dishes. I felt the quantity did not match the price well.  Other then that a wonderful culinary experience.
author: Sunil N.

description: The food was really good. The entrees - black cod and short rib - were especially amazing. The atmosphere and decor are a little tacky and the space doesn't seem intimate or relaxed.
author: Jessica A.

description: I really enjoyed the restaurant and hope they manage to survive in this very odd location. It's a lovely space and they've done some acoustic work,  we were able to talk normally (unlike every other hip new restaurant). We enjoyed all the dishes, but what struck us were that some of the very traditional Indian dishes such as dal and naan were truely sublime. I'm not sure why people are complaining about portion sizes, as two of us were stuffed with two appetizers and two main courses.
author: Gisela S.

description: Amazing food. Really great Indian flavors and very unexpected pleasant flavor combinations. Loved their cocktails very innovative and different. Service could have been better. It was too rushed even.. lot of our food was served together rather than giving enough time between appetizers and main dishes. Overall good experience.
author: Pooja S.

description:
I rarely write a review this low, as I am generally an easy going person and can be easily pleased in a restaurant, but when I pay a fortune to have bad service and leave hungry, I have to share. 
We arrived and were seated quickly, so the concerns I had from reading other reviews were immediately allayed. The ambiance is lovely, cool colors, art, lighting, etc. and the drink menu was really cool. I would have had more drinks, except that no one came back to offer me another. So one drink it was! 
The servers were all lovely people. Very sweet and when they were with us, gave some input. However, with the small plates style of this restaurant, we thought we would have the dishes somewhat staged out. Instead, we drank our drinks, sat there with empty glasses and waited for an extraordinarily long time to get all things served at once. 
The food was delicious tasting, but it has clearly sat in the kitchen for a while, as it was about room temp. Also, the servers forgot 2 parts of the order, which would have been an appetizer. 
The servings are quite small, so it is key to order more than you would think initially. We thought we were ordering a lot of food, but it was light. Again, this is fine and I know it is a fine dining experience, but with better service, this would not be an issue. 
I am sure that Rooh will go on to be very successful if they can get the system right, but I left feeling pretty disappointed and did not feel the experience matched the price point.
author: Emily P.

description: The food was amazing and it was an awesome twist on Indian food. We had the tasting menu and every single course was an incredible surprise. Can't say enough good things about this place!
author: Sharat A.

description: Loved the innovative take on Indian food. If you are tired of the typical Paneer Masalas and the Butter Chicken, go here!
author: Gautam S.

description:
This was our second time at Rooh. We tried the Sunday brunch and it was absolutely delicious, we were stuffed to the point that we couldn't move!
We ordered the Paneer Tikka kulcha which came with a chickpea curry, mango chutney and raita. This was our favorite. The potato tikki topped with spinach and kale tempura was scrumptious too. Highly recommend the Cauliflower 65 as well.
They were out of the kheema which was a bummer because that's my favorite dish here. We ended our meal with rice kheer with pieces of strawberry and sesame chikki. Yum!
author: Zehra L.

description:
My girlfriend and I made a reservation and went there for dinner on a Saturday.  Overall, it was fantastic and we'll definitely be going back there.  Here are some thoughts:

Ambiance: The feel of the place was great, not a stuffy, fancy restaurant in that regard.  The decor felt like English influenced Indian spot.  Bright colors, people around walking and talking.  

Service:  The service was great.  The servers were incredibly knowledgeable and they educate you on your dishes as they arrive with the ingredients, intention, flavors, etc.

Food:  What can I say?  Everything we ate was absolutely delicious.  We started with the pappadams and the 3 chutneys.  They were incredible and the chutneys were unlike anything I've tasted.  Then we had the tuna small plate, which was a deconstructed crudo.  It was perfect.  Then we had the sea bass, which was covered in this deliciously rich sauce that tasted like a lobster bisque without the lobster.  Finally we had the mushroom tandoori.  Holy hell, that was the best tasting mushroom anything I've ever eaten and will order this every time  I go back.  Then there were the drinks.  We had the margerita-ish drink (forgive me, I can't remember the names of these things).  They put some seasoning in there that made it so damn good and unique.

Any downsides?  I will say, it was a bit expensive. For the 2 of us, we had a small plate, 2 big plates, 4 drinks, and an appetizer.  With tip, it was over $200.  That being said, we will go back and just order less.
author: David P.

description: Really good food. It is delightful to taste all the right flavors and something extra in each of their dishes. The tasting menu is amazing, definitely recommend that one. Their cocktail selection is fun!
author: Sangram P.

description:
Went last night. Great decor. The cocktail menu was interesting. I ordered Bombay Sherbet and it was okay. 
We ordered asparagus and kheema for appetizers. Kheema had good flavor and the asparagus was fresh but uninteresting. There was a complimentary frozen goat cheese dipped in chocolate amuse bouche which was not good. 
For the main we ordered fish which was tough but the sauce on the side with seafood was tasty and the seafood was fresh. The multigrain pilaf was excellent the bread basket was okay at best and the butter chicken was average. We ordered the carrot cake w kulfi for dessert and this was excellent. They use good ingredients but taste wise the food is average. Two drinks plus this food w tax and tip $185. Won't go back.
author: Sheila P.

description: Meh. It's was exponentially low on culinary experience compared to take Camden but linear drop in price
author: vud s.

description: Had a delicious dinner here tonight. We ordered the potato tikki, butter chicken and lamb short ribs. The flavors were perfect. We left extremely full yet none of the dishes felt too heavy. Both our server and the host were so friendly and knowledgable despite our walking in 20 mins late to a reservation. Can't wait to come back.
author: Alison Y.

description: Came here for a quick bite during their happy hour. I was impressed by the service and the decor. I ordered the shrimp sausage and the goat cheese/beet croquettes. The shrimp sausage was spiced and cooked well. The croquettes were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Both dishes came with chutneys that were spicy and delicious. I want to come back here again especially to try their tasting menu.
author: Zainub A.

description: I was pleasantly surprised at how delicious the food was here. Although a tad pricey, the quality, taste and presentation was amazing. I had the veggie burger Nc my friends all had the chicken malai tikka and they loved it. The chutney sampler is to die for. Ambiance also very nice.
author: Hunter P.

description: Had a great dinner with my GF. Arrived late on Saturday night and they super happy to seat us (sorry for coming in so late). Host sat us quickly by the window. Staff were extremely calm and knowledgable. They recommended the perfect dishes for us. Left full to the brim. Will be back for sure.
author: Khalid M.

description: Awesome restaurant! Delicate and unique tastes which dazzle the taste buds. A true gem in the heart of an up and coming food district. The beef short ribs were scrumptious, as was the lamb. Walked away a very happy customer :)
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Being a foodie, I am always on the hunt for great Indian food. Well my search stopped here! ROOH is amazing! Hands down, then best Indian I have had in the US.
Came here for a celebratory dinner and was not let down. The tasting menu is the way to go. The meal started with Pani puri and a Burrata bon bon which were both a modern twist on classic Indian dishes. This was followed by the liquid egg Bhurji, which i think was the highlight of the menu. The crispy lamb ribs were perfectly cooked with the meat falling off the bone.and the butter chicken was phenomenal.
The carrot cake halwa for dessert was the perfect end to the perfect meal. The service was amazing, the drinks were varied and  wonderful. The manager walked around interacting with the diners, asking them what they thought of the meal. A complimentary glass of dessert wine was brought out to end the meal.
Would I go here again? YES!
Best Indian food SF for sure.
author: Su Z.

description: I definitely spoke with a man when I dialed the number for your restaurant at 4:49pm on 7/12. Feel free to check again.
author: Neal S.

description: Read a fantastic review of Rooh before making a reservation and it absolutely lived up to expectations! We ordered a bunch of small plates to taste and loved them all - Tuna Bhel (very much like poke with avocado) and Malai Broccoli were the standouts. The only one we wished had more Indian flavors was the burrata and tomato, but I imagine they'll evolve this dish with time. They have a great wine list and drinks menu as well - you'll have a wide variety to choose from. Great for a night out!
author: Kim B.

description: They still need to work out staffing - only 1 person behind the bar when the restaurant was full is Not enough! But the menu was unique, and the food was super flavorful and very good. The 1 cocktail i tried (all are $13) was tasty. The white wines were good. Staff were all quite nice and welcoming, if overstretched. Pricier so i won't go all of the time, but for a nice night out, will definitely come back.
author: jml j.

description: We just came back from dinner here. I am frankly surprised at some of the 5 star reviews here.. Dont get me wrong. The food is quite delicious. But the service is terrible to say the least.. If I am paying $30 for a single entree, I expect good servers who can remember an order that was told to them just a minute ago.. he forgot our water and drinks.. we had to ask the hostess to fetch it for us from the bar where our drinks had been waiting for us over 10 min.. After some complaining to the other server, he came back to check in on us.. He frankly couldn't have cared less about us being there. I am quite disappointed. I would rather go somewhere else and spend my hard earned money.. I will definitely not be returning!
author: Pri S.

description: Really good mocktails. Great place to go with a group. Loved there potato tikki salad. The service is amazing too
author: bhagyashree b.

description: A wonderful place that provides more than just great food, but a guided dining experience. Indian food is very complex, and Rooh really takes it yet another step further, with truly knowledgeable servers that walk diners through the process. Their professionalism and dedication is commendable. Prepare for a relaxed, lengthy meal, and experience tastes and textures that may surprise you. It's more than just a very good restaurant. A highlight is it's Ayurvedic cocktail "mandala," which is sort of a map of exotic cocktails based on the basic taste profile one desires. Our table of eight was very impressed, and the vegan diner among us had just as good of a well-rounded, somewhat surprising experience. Too many great individual dishes to single out just a few, so bring your open mind to Rooh and just let the experience unfold, guided by it's professional staff.
author: Tyler D.

description:
A friend was in town for a conference and we made a last minute reservation for 7:30 on a Tuesday. All three of us are vegetarians, and having previously been to Rooh for brunch, we knew that their menu would have lots of options for us. 

The place wasn't packed but pretty lively for a Tuesday night. We ordered four small plates and 1 large plate to share

Beetroot Murraba
Cauliflower 65
Asparagus Pepper Fry
Dahi Puri

Tandoori Seasonal Mushrooms with upma polenta. (Truffle)
Carrot Halwa Cake with Kulfi 

We enjoyed the dahi puri, cauliflower 65, and tandoori mushrooms immensely. The dahi puri came with 6 pieces that you eat whole and was like Pani puri assembled for you with yogurt on top. The cauliflower 65 dish was as delicious as we'd remembered from brunch, with balls of fried cauliflower arranged artfully in a ring on an utthapam (different presentation than the brunch menu). The beetroot murraba was yummy, but not so different from any other beet salad in the bay-- tender chunks of multicolored beets tossed with greens and a tangy dairy counterpoint. The Asparagus fry dish fell flat-- we were envisioning a more South Indian style dish and flavor profile, and we were disappointed with the stalks that were cooked through but didn't really taste like anything beyond asparagus. The tandoori mushrooms were fantastic-- several different varieties baked with that tandoori char and piled onto creamy dreamy upma served polenta style. So good. 

We will likely be back at Rooh sometime soon. If we came again for dinner, we'd probably order the dumplings or paneer off the large plate menu. We'd probably also get the tikkis and paneer chili off the small plate menu. Overall this place is delicious and beautiful and we'd highly recommend to others!
author: T K.

description: Food was decent, but service needs to be improved and more streamlined. When I went in for lunch with a friend, the restaurant was only 30% full, but the host seemed surprised that we didn't have a reservation and he made it seem like it took him some effort to find us a table. Then, we asked if the empty tables had already been reserved, we got a simple "no". After that our waiter didn't even give us time to look at the menu before asking us what we want to order. At the end of the meal, a check was delivered to us without asking whether we would like to see the tea and dessert menu. I would not go back for such a bad dining experience. The food isn't good enough to compensate for the lack of respect to customers.
author: Lynn C.

description: I love I love i love this place a lot this place serve really Indian food because my husband is Indian and he is chef too so I can say the flavor in food depth. It's reminds me of India. Now onward it's my best Indian restaurant in San Francisco.yummy yummy
author: Fau've C.

description: Wow, wow, wow! Absolutely amazing and talented chef. The food is incredible. The flavors, textures, smells, and food presentation truly engaged all senses. Highly recommend prix fixe menu. Will definitely be back!!
author: Amy C.

description:
We just had a 20-person party here on Friday evening.  Everything was terrific.  From the beginning, Anu was very helpful in connecting with me, helping with menu selection, and drink recommendations. She was excellent with following up with me regarding numbers, timing, etc. I even came in and tasted a few items during the day, well in advance.
On the evening of our party, everything was perfect and smooth. Our server Ashley was delightful. Even though there was a lot of vegetarian food, they created a vegetarian main dish for the few strict vegetarians.  
Everyone really, really loved the food.  The potato tikki was a hit, as was the tuna bhel. We also had paneer chili as an appetizer, which was good as well. The traditional butter chicken was a hit, as was the halibut a la plancha. I really liked the black dariy dal as well. For desserts, the masala chai chocolate pave and ice cream was a great treat. 
We also did a flight of Indian whiskies (there is much more than just Indian whiskies, but we thought we would try several Indian whiskies.) That was fun, and got to sample various whiskies. 
It was terrific for a party of 20, and I would definitely come back here again for dinner because the food was that good.
author: Michelle G.

description: i came here for brunch, and i liked it.  we shared about all the chaats, and they were all good.  my fave was the tuna bhel and the potato tikki, but the paneer chili was apparently a hit too. i had eaten so much this past wknd that i didn't eat/drink as much as i would have liked to try, but i will come back for dinner and try more stuff.
author: Helen T.

description: This place was amazing, we were looking for places to eat, and found ROOH. The service was great, and they had amazing recommendations. We went to brunch on Sunday, and the food was AMAZING. I recommend the chicken tikka &a cheddar kulcha, the pain puri, the short ribs curry, and the tuna bhel for brunch, and the banana tart tatin. This was great and I will definitely be returning soon!
author: Sofia C.

description: A must try for Indian food lovers. It's definitely got a twist to the usual that you normally eat. It seems to develop a new taste for Indian food and in spite quite yummy. We tried their bread sampler, dal makhani, artichoke and grain pulao and paneer pinwheel. Its on the expensive side for the quantity but gives a decent fine dine experience.
author: N P.

description:
The Bay Area is unfortunately a breeding ground for horrific Indian restaurants, some still serving all you can eat buffets for $12.99 from the bygone era of outdated steam table Indian fare with low quality ingredients and sub par flavors. Recently we have seen few new arrivals trying to showcase the inherent richness, diversity and complexity which is the bedrock of Indian cuisine. Our dinner experience last night at Rooh, was one that left us quite content and satisfied, presenting a refreshing take on Indian cuisine executed at a high level that is rare to find in the Bay Area. My family and I had been planning on dining at this restaurant ever since it had opened, so we finally decided to go on the occasion of celebrating my birthday. We made our reservation for 8:30 P.M.  and upon our arrival at 8:27, we were seated promptly by the hostess which we appreciated.

 Our waitress Patty explained to us that the head Chef Sujan Sarkar was out of the country and the sous chef Jesse was at the helm of the kitchen for the evening. We sampled a vast array of what the menu had to offer and came to the conclusion that the small plates were far superior to the large ones overall. The potato tikki ($12) was extremely subtle in terms of the spices that were used, while still being very delicious and the kale and spinach tempura provided a nice textural contrast to the dish. The chicken 65 ($15) was crisp on the exterior yet juicy on the inside and the uttapam accompanied it well. The cauliflower mousse served with the asparagus pepper fry ($15) was simple, buttery and absolutely divine - perhaps the standout item from our entire meal. The Alaskan halibut ($29) with khichdi was definitely our favorite dish from the large plates section of the menu. We found the fish to be flaky and flavorful and the khichdi almost mimicked the feeling of eating a risotto. The desserts which are a result of the creative mind of the Pastry chef Ravi, were impressive to say the least. We had the carrot halwa cake ($10) that was served with a creamy pistachio kulfi and the chocolate pave cake ($10) was rich and satisfying. The drinks were just as creative and innovative as the food, with the standout being the Banaras sour cocktail.

While we were impressed with our meal as a whole, we did find some shortcomings in the food that we felt could not be overlooked. The butter chicken pave ($26) was too sweet for our tastes and the lamb chops ($32) were far too bland- perhaps they were not marinated enough or given enough seasoning for the flavors to penetrate through. The chicken malai tikka ($15) was also a dish that we found to be quite one note and had far too much cheese for our liking. The sides of the saffron rice ($5) and the bread sampler ($8) were also lacking in execution and needs much improvement. 
The service at Rooh was another highlight of our dining experience. Our server Patty was very friendly and willing to accommodate all our needs. It was also evident that the gentleman bringing our dishes to the table had a strong understanding of the food being served and was able to explain each dish flawlessly. The ambiance at this restaurant was absolutely incredible. We loved the vibrant and lush colors that were used throughout, and the lighting was dimmed to just the right level. The decor was elegant and sophisticated, while also providing a sufficient amount of whimsy and fun. A minor constructive observation we have regarding the layout of the  kitchen is that, it is secluded away from the dining guests. We feel that a restaurant of this caliber should have the kitchen at the center of the establishment in an open concept which would have provided an added theatrical element to the dining experience. After all, the kitchen is the heart and soul of any restaurant and should be showcased properly instead of just being an afterthought.
At the end of our meal, the Co owner of the restaurant Ms. Anu, came to our table to speak to us about our dining experience which we found to be a very kind gesture on her part. 

My mother is a very accomplished, professional Indian chef in the Bay Area, and she does not get easily impressed with Indian restaurants especially considering the pathetic variety that currently make up the majority of the Indian food scene in the Bay Area, however, she was pleasantly surprised at how much she enjoyed her experience at Rooh. My entire family was in agreement that the dishes were cooked with progressive techniques and presented in a modern way, but that in no way compromised the integrity of what Indian cuisine is. We did not feel the Indian flavors of the dishes were muddled or hidden through the disguise of fusion with other cuisines. It was simply Indian food executed with a unique and creative thought process. If Rooh keeps up its current level of creativity and service and improves on the shortcomings of certain aspects on the menu, we have no doubts that it will continue to prosper.
author: Zareen A.

description: We came for a birthday event and left IMPRESSED. The food here wasn't just filling it was an experience. Having been to some of the other "top" Indian restaurants in San Francisco, this is hands down the best. I'd suggest skipping the tasting menu if you're in a group. Go with a family style kind of game plan and enjoy!
author: Daniel C.

description: Four of us walked in when they opened for dinner. They were fully booked for the evening, but we were able to be seated on the patio. We ordered several cocktails and quite a few of the small plates: the chutney platter, the cauliflower, the potato tikki (a standout), the asparagus, the scallops, a saffron rice, the garlic naan, and the baked chicken (I would skip next time). Everything we had was great. We raved about the food the whole time, until dessert came. We ordered two carrot cakes and one of the chocolate desserts. They were all $10 a piece and maybe two bites. They were really beautiful, but not tasty at all. The ice cream each was served with was icy and not flavorful. The carrot cake itself was kind of dry and honestly looked like end bits of a loaf of bread. We were all really surprised by how bad the desserts were considering how much we enjoyed the rest of dinner. I would totally come back, but I recommend skipping dessert for sure.
author: Jannah T.

description: Menu is confusing. There were 7 of us and it was not clear what we should be ordering so that everyone could have enough. Server should have done a better job in explaining. The service was not that great either. Looks like a good place for a happy hour, but I do not see it as a serious restaurant. The food we had could not be faulted; it was not Indian though.
author: Anil K.

description: Super delicious spin on indian food. Very fresh ingredients and just fantastic food by a really great chef. Ambience is also very nice and modern.
author: Anna A.

description: I was skeptical going in at first as I am a fan of Indian street food, and this place is formal. I was pleasantly surprised with the taste and quality of food. I had a chance to meet with chef Sujan and share his passion for Indian food. I loved the food and service there and will be back there for sure!
author: Vipin T.

description: Can't wait to be back!! Amazing cocktails and Indian food . Definitely THE BEST experience we've in the last few months and we go out frequently. Recommended to all our friends and making reservations for our next time. 6 stars.
author: Sharon P.

description: Eclectic and delicious food! A nice twist on the traditional Indian dishes! Don't miss the Tuna Bhel, Kulchas and Tiramisu Rasmalai!
